____________________________________________________________

Streaming's rising costs help refresh video stores

Autor: Briggs, James. 

Información de publicación: Indianapolis Star ; Indianapolis, Ind. [Indianapolis, Ind]. 26 Jan 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/streamings-rising-costs-help-refresh-video-stores/docview/2344614299/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Streaming%27s+rising+costs+help+refresh+video+stores&amp;author=Briggs%2C+James&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Indianapolis+Star&amp;issn=1930-2533&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: My wife and I finally made time to see the new Star Wars movie, "The Rise of Skywalker," in a theater last week. But, before we did, we wanted to rewatch the two films that preceded it. The challenge was finding them.
I used to – way back, like five years ago – handle tasks like this by Googling the content I wanted to watch and then playing it on one of the handful of existing streaming services I subscribed to. That doesn't really work anymore. As streaming apps are proliferating, the content I'm looking for in most cases turns out to be available on a service that I don't have.
If you want to watch Star Wars films, as we did, then the only way to stream them is to spend $7 a month on a new service called Disney Plus. I am not going to do that, not even for Baby Yoda (at least, not until my 9-month-old son learns what Disney is).
Instead, we went to the Family Video store near our house, paid about $6 to rent both films on Blu-ray and watched them. It was a very 2003 way to spend a weekend. But, as changing times once called for people to adopt streaming technology, the most recent evolution of video content is making video stores great again. At least, the few that remain.
It's expensive to subscribe to everything If you haven't paid attention while driving around Indianapolis, you might be baffled by a reference to video stores in 2020. That's understandable. The once-ubiquitous Blockbuster Video and Hollywood Video chains have been gone for about a decade. They collapsed around the time that video streaming was hitting its peak for consumers.
For a brief golden era, you could subscribe to Netflix, Hulu and, maybe, Amazon Prime Video, and you'd have access to almost all the content you could want – or, at least, so much that you didn't have time to miss the shows and movies that weren't available.
But video stores didn't entirely go extinct – and that era of streaming didn't last long. Much like 2010, we are again at a turning point.
Now, if you want access to everything that the internet has to offer on demand, you have to pay monthly fees to all the early players, plus newcomers including CBS All Access, ESPN Plus, Apple TV Plus and the aforementioned Disney Plus. That doesn't include the cost of cable or live-television services such as YouTube TV, or longtime premium services such as HBO and Showtime. Soon, there will be even more options, including NBC's upcoming streaming service, called Peacock, and a short-form video app called Quibi.
You could easily spend more than $200 a month to ensure you always have immediate access to the programming you want. But your best, most cost-effective option for watching something in 2020 might be renting it on a title-by-title basis.
Just like the old days.
Video stores remain in Indy At a time when no one thinks about video stores, Indianapolis is uniquely well served by them. Family Video, a chain with hundreds of locations, mostly in the Midwest, still has several stores across the city.
While everyone might have been fed up with late fees 10 years ago, Family Video now offers an oasis for people fed up with paying for new subscriptions. Even accounting for the notorious late fee, it is now generally cheaper to go into a Family Video and rent a movie or TV show than it is to pay for whatever streaming service has the content you want.
And, while Family Video might be the only video store left standing in Indianapolis, it is not the only option for a la carte video borrowing. There are still Redbox locations everywhere and you can probably rent what you're looking for at no cost from the public library (though you might have to wait for it).
I realize there are some problems with my argument that borrowing DVDs is suddenly relevant again.
Do you own a DVD or Blu-ray player? Even Family Video has been closing stores lately.
Overall DVD consumption is in a perpetual free fall. DVD sales plummeted from $10 billion in 2010 to about a third of that now, according to Digital Entertainment Group data cited by The Los Angeles Times.
That ties in with perhaps the biggest problem. As one of my colleagues pointed out when I mentioned this idea, she doesn't own a DVD player. That would certainly make it hard to watch a DVD.
If you don't own a device that plays DVDs, it's a good time to consider getting one. Even if the idea of reverting back to renting movies doesn't appeal to you, it's worth considering whether it might be better to just buy the content you watch rather than pay endless monthly fees for access that could end at some point.
Veronica Walsingham made this point well last week in a thoughtful New York Times essay that imagines it's 2022 and she has realized it was a mistake to pay for streaming services that keep splintering.
"We never outsmarted the entertainment industry when we opted for Netflix subscriptions over cable," Walsingham writes. "Instead, we gave the industry a way to monetize our love of one or two television shows forever."
From cable bundles to apps, studios are good at finding ways to capture the most money for their content. When they evolve, consumers should consider doing the same, even if it feels like a step backward.
Contact IndyStar metro columnist James Briggs at 317-444-6307. Follow him on Twitter: @JamesEBriggs.
Family Video, a chain with hundreds of locations, mostly in the Midwest, still has several stores across Indianapolis. The chain offers an oasis for people fed up with paying for new subscriptions.
file photos by Robert Scheer/indyStar
Family Video has survived an increase in digital services that spelled the end for Blockbuster Video and others.
CREDIT: JAMES BRIGGS

Families living with epilepsy get support

Autor: Noonan, Lisa. 

Información de publicación: Rochester Democrat and Chronicle ; Rochester, N.Y. [Rochester, N.Y]. 26 Jan 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/families-living-with-epilepsy-get-support/docview/2344614274/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Families+living+with+epilepsy+get+support&amp;author=Noonan%2C+Lisa&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Rochester+Democrat+and+Chronicle&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: What does it mean to have a child with epilepsy?
It means holding your breath every time she has a seizure.
It means worrying every time she goes off to school that I will get "the call."
It means making unexpected trips to the hospital while on vacation out of state.
My daughter's first seizure happened when she was 18 months old. As I held my shaking toddler in my arms, Alexandra turned blue and I thought she was dying. That seizure happened 21 years ago, but the memory of it is still as fresh today as it was the day it happened.
That seizure changed our lives. The journey that it sent us on was long and filled with setbacks. Finding the right combination of medications to control seizures and minimize side effects can be difficult as medications affect each person differently and it can take a lot of trial and error to find the right combination.
And once the doctors get it right, your child has a growth spurt and you have to start again.
While epilepsy, and everything that came with it, has been a struggle for us, I am so very thankful. Years ago, one of Alex's neurologists recommended that I connect with the local epilepsy support agency — Epilepsy-Pralid Inc. I immediately joined the board and got Alex involved in their programs.
Through my work with EPI, I have met many families who have it much worse — who struggle daily with seizures, with multiple children with epilepsy, and with the financial burden of a chronic medical condition.
EPI helps these families through a number of supports and services. We provide important epilepsy education services and seizure first aid training — from sitting down with newly diagnosed families to educating school health classes. EPI connects families through networking groups, recreation opportunities, a college scholarship, teen weekend retreats and summer camps.
Much of this work receives financial support from the Chocolate Ball, EPI's annual gala dedicated to raising awareness and support for our epilepsy services. The Chocolate Ball is a night of fundraising and celebration. This community offers much to those affected by epilepsy — education, networking, support — but there is still much work to be done.
Come celebrate with us on Feb. 1, 2020, as we host the 34th annual Chocolate Ball. Taste award-winning, Food Network-worthy cakes, made by local bakers right here in Rochester. Listen to our keynote speaker, Kurt Eichenwald, a former New York Times investigative journalist who has struggled with epilepsy since college. Learn about how Camp EAGR, our sleepaway summer camp for kids with epilepsy changes lives.
Don't miss out on Rochester's sweetest gala — check it out at epiny.org.
Lisa Noonan is a mom of a child with epilepsy and board member of Epilepsy-Pralid Inc.
Lisa Noonan and her daughter
Provided
CREDIT: Lisa Noonan

Latinos in Iowa prepare to partake in 'el caucus' But activists decry lack of interpreters for emerging bloc

Autor: Medina, Jennifer. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 26 Jan 2020: A.23.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/latinos-iowa-prepare-partake-el-caucus-activists/docview/2344614090/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Latinos+in+Iowa+prepare+to+partake+in+%27el+caucus%27+But+activists+decry+lack+of+interpreters+for+emerging+bloc&amp;author=Medina%2C+Jennifer&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.23&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Charlie Harris, Diesel the Cat sleuth once more

Autor: O'Bryan, Susan. 

Información de publicación: The Clarion Ledger ; Jackson, Miss. [Jackson, Miss]. 26 Jan 2020: B.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/charlie-harris-diesel-cat-sleuth-once-more/docview/2344613971/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Charlie+Harris%2C+Diesel+the+Cat+sleuth+once+more&amp;author=O%27Bryan%2C+Susan&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Clarion+Ledger&amp;issn=0744-9526&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: A Maine coon cat and its inquisitive owner take center stage in "Careless Whiskers," (Berkley Prime Crime/Penguin Random House), the latest novel by Miranda James. It's the 12th installment in the New York Times best-selling author's "Cat in the Stacks" series.
Miranda James is the pseudonym of Dean James, a seventh-generation Mississippian who recently returned to his home state after 30 years in Texas, according to his website, catinthstacks.com. Whether writing under the pen name or his own, Dean James has fans eager for mystery and suspense with cozy, down-home heart and humor.
Charlie Harris is a librarian at a small college in fictional Athena, Mississippi. The widower is passionate about his family and friends, justice for all, and about an arrogant cat named Diesel. The cat goes everywhere with Charlie, including the college theatre where his daughter, Laura, is co-starring in a play directed by her husband, Frank Salisbury.
It's there that Charlie and Diesel get caught up in their latest adventure, even though Charlie has sworn off crime-fighting. A guest performer, Luke Lombardi, whose fame is fading faster than a falling star, is poisoned on stage.
The cast of suspects include Laura, who handed him the poisoned drink, a mysterious stranger sneaking around backstage, an odd playwright with location connections, and two French followers (one a lover, one an employee) of the now-dead actor. Is one of these people also threatening Charlie's daughter, or is there someone else lurking in the wings?
James keeps readers entertained with an easy-flowing dialogue and well-developed characters. Readers can identify with the cast and settings. As befitting a well-educated character, Charlie Harris has a way with words and literary references. Recurring characters, such as the Ducote sisters, Melba and Azalea, and developing relationships between humans and pets bring home the small-town feel of neighborhoods and family dinners.
And although this novel is part of a series, it can be read as a stand-alone with easy-to-follow throwbacks to earlier stories. The series began with "Murder Past Due" in 2010, and a new novel has been released each year since then. The next — and 13th — novel, "Cat Me if You Can," is due out in August.
Susan O'Bryan was a journalist for 30 years before she joined the University of Mississippi Medical Center in 2010 as a web content coordinator. She is a freelance writer for several newspapers and literary review.
CREDIT: Susan O'Bryan

Lugar: Texas New York Maine Mississippi

Film on fashion photographer hits Island first

Autor: Guzmán, Rafer. 

Información de publicación: Newsday , Combined editions; Long Island, N.Y. [Long Island, N.Y]. 26 Jan 2020: 16.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/film-on-fashion-photographer-hits-island-first/docview/2344613555/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Film+on+fashion+photographer+hits+Island+first&amp;author=Guzm%C3%A1n%2C+Rafer&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=16&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Newsday&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Call it the documentary that almost never was. "The Times of Bill Cunningham," Mark Bozek's portrait of the late, legendary fashion photographer, began as a one-minute video clip for an awards ceremony in 1993. More than 25 years later, Bozek's raw interview footage has been transformed into a feature-length documentary that will arrive in theaters Feb. 14. Bozek will bring his film in person to Huntington's Cinema Arts Centre Feb. 1 at 3 p.m.
"I started this as a kind of side project," says Bozek, a first-time filmmaker who compiled an early cut of the movie on a laptop in his Huntington home. "Instead it took over my life for the last two-and-a-half years."
Bozek, 60, may not be a Long Island native - he's from Michigan -but he has a couple of strong connections to the area. For one, he's the guy who discovered East Meadow's Joy Mangano while she was selling her now-famous Miracle Mops on the QVC shopping channel, where he was Senior Vice President of Broadcasting. (David O. Russell's biopic "Joy" featured a version of him played by Bradley Cooper. "I will mention that for the rest of my life," Bozek says). His wife, Susan, hails from Oyster Bay; they moved to Huntington in 2003.
Having also worked in the apparel industry for a time, Bozek was familiar with Cunningham, a self-taught photographer who became famous for his journalistic approach to fashion. Cunningham was a mainstay at The New York Times for nearly 30 years and a contributor to Details magazine; he also mounted several exhibits of his work. At the same time, Cunningham avoided the limelight himself, preferring instead to be known as just another New York eccentric - the old guy on the bike, wearing his trademark blue jacket and taking snapshots all over the city.
Bozek was working as a producer Fox Television, he says, when he began pursuing Cunningham for an interview in 1993. Cunningham refused, but later called back to ask a favor: He was receiving a fashion-industry award and didn't want to attend the ceremony -- would Bozek mind videotaping a short acceptance speech? Bozek grabbed a camera and several Betacam videocassettes and showed up to Cunningham's studio - a kitchen-less, bathroom-less apartment above Carnegie Hall -- for what turned into a non-stop, four-hour talk session. (Cunningham's place was so dark that they filmed in a friend's apartment in the same building.)
Bozek isn't sure why Cunningham spoke so candidly that day. "I'm no Barbara Walters," he says. Even when Cunningham began to shed tears - while talking about his own shyness, for instance -- he insisted the camera keep rolling. "After about 45 minutes I realized I should just keep quiet," Bozek recalls. The interview ended only when the tape ran out.
The day of Cunningham's death, in 2016, Bozek dug out those now-obsolete Betacam tapes. He found a company that could digitize them, then began piecing together what would become "The Times of Bill Cunningham." He showed a rough cut to the late photographer's friends, whom he says gave it their blessing; a meeting with Cunningham's niece, Patricia Simonson, who controls his archives, resulted in access to roughly 3 million photographs. A proposal for Sarah Jessica Parker to serve as narrator met with a quick yes. The film is being released by Greenwich Entertainment, which helped release the Oscar-winning documentary "Free Solo" in 2018.
"Some people say he would have hated all this attention," Bozek says of Cunningham. "But other of his friends say the opposite - that in his own way, he would have loved this."

ANYTHING CAN HAPPEN IN IOWA THE HAWKEYE STATE IS KNOWN FOR ITS DARING DECISIONS

Autor: Shribman, David M. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: E-3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/anything-can-happen-iowa-hawkeye-state-is-known/docview/2344612688/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=ANYTHING+CAN+HAPPEN+IN+IOWA+THE+HAWKEYE+STATE+IS+KNOWN+FOR+ITS+DARING+DECISIONS&amp;author=Shribman%2C+David+M&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E-3&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: It's less than 10 days before Iowans, possibly braving bitter cold and blowing snow, head to school libraries, church basements, community centers and veterans' halls to begin the formal process of choosing the Democratic presidential nominee. The outcome is as uncertain as the weather.
Iowans are accustomed to making daring decisions. They chose a former director of central intelligence, George H.W. Bush, over a conservative icon who had been a two-term governor of California, Ronald Reagan, in 1980. Some 28 years later they chose an unknown senator from Illinois, Barack Obama, over a onetime vice-presidential nominee, John Edwards, and a first lady-turned-senator, Hillary Clinton.
Almost three-quarters of the winners of contested races in Iowa since 1972 have won their party's nomination, but just two (Jimmy Carter and Mr. Obama) won the White House. So Iowa sets the table but doesn't necessarily serve up the meal.
Even so, no one doubts the importance of the caucuses, and no one, except former Mayor Mike Bloomberg of New York, is willing to bypass them. And this time, the struggle to win Iowa is more obscured than usual.
"This contest is far more unsettled than most," says a veteran caucus observer, Dennis Goldford, a political scientist at Des Moines' Drake University. "There is nobody running away with this. Iowa caucuses bring surprises, and right now there is no clear front-runner. Huge numbers are undecided or subject to change their minds. Anyone who would predict the winner would be foolish."
That's partially because no one knows whether Amy Klobuchar is surging. Her poll numbers are low, but she has visited all 99 counties and is airing ads like mad. She's the senator from Minnesota, which shares a long border at 43º 30' N, roughly near the divide between the watersheds of the Des Moines, Iowa and Blue Earth rivers. Geography matters. For one thing, it makes it easy for her supporters to flood across the border to assist her candidacy.
The 1988 caucuses are illustrative. They were won by Rep. Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, which borders Iowa at the south, with Sen. Paul Simon of Illinois, which borders Iowa to the east, coming in second. (Geography is not infallible. Rep. Michelle Bachman of Minnesota came in sixth in a field of seven in 2012, with barely over 6,000 votes.)
No one knows for sure whether former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., has peaked. He led the polls in the state from mid-November through the end of December but may have faded since then. Former Vice President Joe Biden has been leading in recent days, but his fortunes have risen and fallen like the levels of the Mississippi River, where the Iowa cities of Burlington, Bettendorf, Davenport, Dubuque and Marquette sit.
Those are only some of the moving parts bearing on the caucuses. Indeed, there have been several changes in the structure of the contest in recent days, and the most significant have come from the East, which has shaped Iowa since the Black Hawk Treaty of 1833 opened most of the state to white settlement. The 2020 influences come from New York and Washington.
From New York comes The New York Times' double endorsement of Ms. Klobuchar and Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. Though candidates actively seek the endorsement of The Des Moines Register, newspaper endorsements ordinarily do not provide substantial boosts to candidates. (Best example: In 1972, the Manchester Union Leader supported Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles in the Democratic race. Yorty won 6% of the vote that year.) Endorsements from far away - especially from New York, especially from The Times, especially at a time of press distrust - have little possibility of possessing much weight.
But this one might. No one will vote for the Minnesotan on the basis of The Times recommendation. But the endorsement has the potential of elevating Ms. Klobuchar into the top tier. Then anything can happen.
The second factor is in Washington, also where anything can happen - except perhaps a Senate vote removing President Donald Trump from office.
But the Senate trial now underway requires all sitting senators to do exactly that - sit. And by sitting in the Senate chamber, Ms. Klobuchar, Ms. Warren and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont aren't running in Iowa. They are hostages to the Senate trial, leaving Mr. Biden and Mr. Buttigieg with all the airtime and attention. The three senators at the top of the race are sidelined. So is Sen. Michael Bennet of Colorado, who is struggling for air in the presidential race and now is essentially out of breath.
The Times editorial does in some way reshape the race, which once had a progressive lane (Mr. Sanders, Ms. Warren, perhaps others now departed), a moderate lane (Mr. Buttigieg, Ms. Klobuchar) and an outsider lane (Mr. Bloomberg, Tom Steyer and Andrew Yang).
But now it is possible to see the Democratic race differently, and to discern a new architecture to the contest.
With the pairing of Ms. Warren and Ms. Klobuchar, the race now has a female lane, pitting the two endorsed candidates against each other, and a blue-collar-appeal lane, pitting Mr. Sanders, who speaks of workers' rights and excoriates the wealthy, against Mr. Biden, who also has appeal for working folks. Why else would a fight break out between the two men over Social Security, a vital retirement income supplement for working Americans?
Now add another new development.
A study conducted by the Yale and George Mason centers on climate change communication separates Americans into categories depending on their views on climate change. For the first time, the segment "alarmed" about climate change has reached 31%, nearly triple its size five years ago, while those who were dismissive or doubtful of the effect of climate change have decreased.
Does that mean anything politically? Almost certainly it does, in the long run. In the short run, it may be a boost to Mr. Steyer, who relentlessly has trumpeted the cause of climate change. Iowa is for upsets. That would be the biggest one of all time. It's unlikely, almost out of the question. But a month ago, most of this column would have been considered just that way.
David M. Shribman is a former and now emeritus executive editor of the Post-Gazette and a nationally syndicated columnist. He is a visiting professor at McGill University in Montreal (dshribman@post-gazette.com).

WHITE HOUSE LAWYERS PROCLAIM TRUMP'S INNOCENCE, QUESTION DEMOCRATS' MOTIVES PRESIDENT'S TEAM SAYS AID BLOCK WAS NORMAL

Autor: Moore, Daniel. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: A-1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/white-house-lawyers-proclaim-trumps-innocence/docview/2344609585/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=WHITE+HOUSE+LAWYERS+PROCLAIM+TRUMP%27S+INNOCENCE%2C+QUESTION+DEMOCRATS%27+MOTIVES+PRESIDENT%27S+TEAM+SAYS+AID+BLOCK+WAS+NORMAL&amp;author=Moore%2C+Daniel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A-1&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: WASHINGTON - The White House legal team opened arguments on Saturday in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial by saying Mr. Trump did "nothing wrong" and that House Democrats had "hid evidence" in the last three days that would have proved the president's innocence.
"They have the burden of proof, and they have not come close to meeting it," said White House Counsel Pat Cipollone at the start of a two-hour session on the floor of the U.S. Senate.
He portrayed the Democrats' efforts to remove Mr. Trump from office less than a year before Americans go to the polls as "the most massive interference in an election in American history."
Mr. Trump's defense lawyers attempted to undercut arguments presented by a team of six House Democrats for nearly 24 hours over the last three days.
Democrats have asserted that Mr. Trump abused his power by freezing nearly $400 million in security aid to Ukraine and by withholding a coveted White House meeting in an attempt to pressure the American ally to dig up dirt on former Vice President Joe Biden. Mr. Biden is running for the Democratic nomination in this year's presidential election.
After a 12-week impeachment inquiry last fall, the House of Representatives voted in December to impeach Mr. Trump on two articles: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.
But Mr. Cipollone said on Saturday that conclusion was wrong, calling attention to parts of the summary of Mr. Trump's July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy.
The summary, which the White House released last September, includes talks between the two leaders about broad anti-corruption efforts, and U.S. efforts to push Europe to do more to help Ukraine.
"Yes, you are absolutely right," Mr. Zelenskiy told Mr. Trump, according to the White House summary of the call, read aloud by Mr. Cipollone. "Not only 100 percent, but actually 1,000 percent."
Mr. Zelenskiy went on to tell Mr. Trump he had recently told German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron "they are not doing quite as much as they need to be doing" and that "I'm very grateful to you for that because the United States is doing quite a lot for Ukraine."
The White House strategy attempted to rebut claim House Democrats' claim that Mr. Trump cared only about his re-election prospects and that the president diverged from established U.S. foreign policy in temporarily freezing the aid to Ukraine.
Jay Sekulow, an attorney for Mr. Trump, pointed to several other instances in 2018 and 2019 that the Trump administration had decided to temporarily freeze or renegotiate military aid to other countries.
Aid was held in those cases, Mr. Sekulow said, due to concerns that those countries were not sharing enough of the burden in fighting corruption, terrorism or other problems identified by U.S. officials.
Aid was withheld to Afghanistan, Pakistan, Lebanon, El Salvador and South Korea, he said. Such decisions were routine practice, he said, pointing to sworn testimony by Fiona Hill, a Russia expert formerly at the National Security Council, and other witnesses called by House Democrats to testify in the impeachment inquiry.
Therefore, Mr. Trump acted within his right to question the nearly $400 million in military aid due to Ukraine, he said.
"To say the president of the United States was not concerned about burden-sharing, that he was not concerned about corruption in Ukraine ... the facts establish exactly the opposite," Mr. Sekulow said.
White House lawyers also claimed Ukrainian officials could have felt no pressure because they were unaware of the hold on U.S. aid at the time of Mr. Zelenskiy's July 25 phone call with Mr. Trump.
The aid to Ukraine was ultimately released, and Mr. Zelenskiy got his meeting with Mr. Trump at the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Poland on Sept. 25. The importance to Mr. Zelenskiy of having that meeting in the Oval Office specifically was overblown by Democrats, Mr. Sekulow said.
The lawyers said Mr. Zelenskiy publicly described the July 25 phone conversation - while sitting beside Mr. Trump at the U.N. meeting - as a "good phone call" and "normal" and insisted that "nobody pushed him."
The Democrats "think you can read minds," Mr. Sekulow said. "I think you look at the words."
That argument resonated with some Senate Republicans.
"Now you know the rest of the story," Sen. James Lankford, R-Okla., told reporters after the session concluded. The defense team exposed, Mr. Lankford said, the Democrats' case relied on "innuendo" and "secret motivations and presumptions" instead of facts.
By presenting a different view of what witnesses said, the White House strategy could complicate a looming fight over whether the Senate should vote to call witnesses or issue subpoenas for documents.
Senate Democrats have been demanding four key witnesses testify as part of the trial, a move Senate Republicans have resisted. On Tuesday, the Republican-controlled chamber voted down a slew of Democratic attempts, by repeated 53-47 party-line votes, to obtain more information.
The Senate will revisit the question as soon as Thursday.
Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va., told reporters he thought "the case for witnesses and documents has gotten even stronger" with the White House defense. The lawyers' insistence that Mr. Trump should have been able to cross-examine witnesses lends weight to the Democrats' push to call them, he said.
Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., said the lawyers' focus on the July 25 phone call gives senators a limited view of Mr. Trump's scheme.
In particular, Mr. Casey said, he wants to see a cable written by Bill Taylor, former acting U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, expressing concerns to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo about the president's actions.
"A lot of the facts could be better considered if we had witnesses and documents," Mr. Casey said in an interview after the session. "You often see the corruption after you've seen the totality of the evidence."
Meanwhile, Sen. Pat Toomey, R-Pa., has questioned the need for witnesses. Mr. Toomey said on Saturday he would support a witness if they could resolve a disputed key fact - "the resolution of which would change my mind on my final conclusion."
So far, he said, nothing in the case would benefit from witnesses. The White House team merely provided "more complete testimony," rather than leaving key facts open to dispute, he explained.
"The Democrats left out all the elements that contradicts their narrative," Mr. Toomey said. "It's clear the impeachment managers intended to mislead with the witness testimony."
One point of agreement between the two sides: the seriousness of the decision before the Senate.
Mr. Cipollone, facing all 100 senators who are confined to their desks, said the president's removal would result in unprecedented upheaval.
"They're asking you to tear up all of the ballots across the country," he said. "I don't think they spent one minute of their 24 hours talking to you about the consequences of that to our country."
The defense lawyers portrayed the House impeachment inquiry as a rushed, unfair process that denied the president due process rights.
"They had a timetable to meet, they wanted to have impeachment done by Christmas," said Patrick F. Philbin, deputy counsel to the president.
Mr. Philbin also attacked the credibility of the whistleblower and faulted Democrats for not launching an inquiry into that person's potential bias or political motive for filing the report.
He suggested Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif. - who as chair of the House Intelligence Committee led the impeachment inquiry last fall - could have been colluding with that person.
Mr. Schiff "had a reason to not have that inquiry," Mr. Philbin said.
After the session, Mr. Schiff called that notion "nonsense." He said that he followed the law by referring the whistleblower to the intelligence community's inspector general.

DECOLONIZING HISTORY AT JUSTICE SUMMIT GATHERERS TALK ABOUT DISCRIMINATION, ALGORITHMS

Autor: Litvak, Anya. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: C-1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/decolonizing-history-at-justice-summit-gatherers/docview/2344609583/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=DECOLONIZING+HISTORY+AT+JUSTICE+SUMMIT+GATHERERS+TALK+ABOUT+DISCRIMINATION%2C+ALGORITHMS&amp;author=Litvak%2C+Anya&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C-1&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: If decolonizing history sounds like a lot for one day, the Pittsburgh Racial Justice Summit was jam-packed with trying.
"Who gets to tell the story?" was a question repeated and reframed throughout the halls of the Pittsburgh Theological Seminary on Saturday during workshops on environmental justice, housing discrimination, art representation and even algorithms.
Carl Redwood Jr., a community organizer in the Hill District who grew up around the corner from the Highland Avenue venue, opened with an example from his youth.
Every day, he'd walk past a sign that declared the establishment of Highland Park to have been "settled in 1778."
The story that sign told was about Alexander Negley, a Swiss soldier and blacksmith who became the first white settler to make a home in this part of East Liberty - an area that is now, again, quickly gentrifying.
The indigenous people who were here before Negley and who were displaced from this river valley by similar settlements aren't considered in that sign, Mr. Redwood said.
"Who gets to tell the story? All of us get to tell the story," proclaimed Tarek Abuata, a Palestinian-born activist who moved to Houston when he was 6.
His history of the founding of the State of Israel was much different than the history that Rabbi Brant Rosen, of Chicago, learned from stories of his parents and grandparents.
Rabbi Rosen, sitting next to Mr. Abuata, talked about how that history changed over time, as he started to listen to the stories of individual Palestinians.
The Pittsburgh Racial Justice Summit, in its 22nd iteration this year, is put on by the Black and White Reunion, an organization founded in 1996, a year after the death of Jonny Gammage. Mr. Gammage, a black driver, died of asphyxiation in the custody of police in suburban Pittsburgh during a traffic stop.
This year, the gathering was dedicated to a mainstay of the Black and White Reunion, Ann Mason, who died in November.
"She was just a human being who bridged the gap between races," Tim Stevens, a co-founder of the summit and CEO of the Black Political Empowerment Project, said of his friend. "Today, you're here to emulate the work of Ann Mason."
The organizing committee initially intended to name the summit "1619 to 2020," a reference to the year when African people were brought to the United States as slaves and the subject of a massive New York Times project that frames all major aspects of modern American life as a linear result of 246 years of slavery.
In the end, the title was changed to 1492 to 2020, to take into account the indigenous people who were displaced and colonized with the arrival of Christopher Columbus in North America at the end of the 15th century.
It was a theme of the day to pan out further.
Alex Jackson, a student at Carnegie Mellon University, drew a line from history into the digital future in a workshop about the biases built into algorithms that govern increasingly more aspects of our lives.
"Data [is] most the valuable product we have right now," Ms. Jackson said.
When data reflects the results of institutions that were built on racism and inequality, using biased data to make predictions will lead to biased predictions, she said.
Ms. Jackson spoke about predictive algorithms used by police departments and judges to inform which neighborhoods get more enforcement or which individuals in the criminal justice system are likely to offend again.
"You're basing these algorithms on historical trends," she said, which perpetuates a loop. Except "now you have it with this 'objectivity' - a computer is telling me I should be going out and policing these neighborhoods."
Algorithms that assume the less an insurance company has paid out, the healthier the insured must be are being used to make decisions about interventions and treatment - and that ends up being biased against minority populations who have historically received worse health care and worse health insurance coverage, Ms. Jackson said.
"Discrimination from our past is now being encoded," she said.
The results of red-lining and credit discrimination are now encoded into algorithms that govern bank loans and interest rates.
"Those things have never been corrected in our society, and so they're going to show up in algorithms," Ms. Jackson cautioned.
Speakers drew attention to historical patterns but urged participants not to resign to them. Mr. Stevens has asked for a list of action steps from each workshop that he hopes to post on the Black and White Reunion website in the near future.
Anya Litvak: alitvak@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1455.

ORNATE CHAMBER BECOMES JURY BOX

Autor: Moore, Daniel. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: E-1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ornate-chamber-becomes-jury-box/docview/2344609069/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=ORNATE+CHAMBER+BECOMES+JURY+BOX&amp;author=Moore%2C+Daniel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E-1&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: WASHINGTON - Americans watching broadcasts of President Donald Trump's impeachment trial last week were treated to a steady diet of individual speakers, with government-operated cameras trained at one of three podiums. Occasionally, during a break in the action, they could see a distant shot of the gilded chamber.
The Senate Press Gallery has a far more expansive view. Perched above the front of chamber, the gallery faces all 100 senators such that reporters can observe their real-time reactions: their attentive postures, fidgets, note-taking, heavy sighs, teeth-picking, leg-stretching, head-shaking, occasional yawning and, perhaps, some nodding off.
Though it betrayed little emotion to journalists attempting to glean any insight into their thinking, the gallery offered the most immediate reading of the country's most powerful jury box - of jurors tasked with deciding whether to remove the president from office.
The historic trial, which began in earnest last Tuesday and will span six days a week until a verdict, created an extraordinary scene that most of the country won't ever see. With the access came unprecedented restrictions on reporting imposed by Senate leadership.
Thanks to the famously stubborn and arcane rules of the U.S. Senate, all electronic devices, including phones or recorders, are banned inside the chamber. No exceptions were allowed for journalists, over objections from the committee that oversees regulations in the press gallery.
The Senate also limited the movement of journalists to "pens" - a few tight spaces partitioned by ropes - when senators took short breaks. The rule effectively prevented reporters from asking questions of any senator who did not decide to walk over and share thoughts. (And there were not many who did so.)
Senate officials said the rules were necessary to ensure the safety of public officials, but reporters pointed out the rules exceeded those imposed during the president's annual State Of The Union speech in the House of Representatives.
The restrictions "fail to acknowledge what currently works on Capitol Hill," read a statement from the Standing Committee of Correspondents, the group of reporters that self-police the press gallery.
The Regional Reporters Association, which represents Washington correspondents working for regional news organizations, including the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, said the rules "serve no purpose but to hinder the public from learning about their public officials and journalists from doing their job to provide that information."
Therefore, the chamber took on the center of the action. Most of the time, the grand room held a sober mood, with stony-faced senators confined to their wooden desks as if at a college lecture. The Senate sergeant-in-arms began each day with a warning - largely symbolic - that senators were required to be silent "under pain of imprisonment."
No coffee was permitted, only glasses of still or sparking water and - thanks to another obscure Senate precedent - milk. (No milk was spotted last week.)
Some senators wrote notes to each other to communicate without speaking. Many senators occasionally stood up stiffly to stretch their legs and to use the bathroom.
The long sessions and short breaks leave little time for senators to interact with their staff, let alone confer with each other, Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., told reporters last Thursday.
"When we're in that chamber, everyone is for the most part, with the exception of rare interactions, people are quiet and listening," Mr. Casey said. "I think it our obligation to sit and listen every minute."
Throughout the day, reporters rushed from the gallery seating, where they took notes on U.S. Senate stationery, back to the gallery's crowded workspace to continually update stories online. While many reporters have assigned desks, some crammed themselves onto communal sofas and into phone booths - a relic that gallery reporters use for privacy.
Trash cans overflowed with coffee cups and scraps from the Senate Carry-Out in the basement.
A sampling of the Senate floor's so-called "candy desk," currently manned by Sen. Pat Toomey, R-Pa., were brought to the gallery at the start of the trial. Provisions brought by Mr. Toomey's staff included Hershey's bars, Rolo caramels, Milky Ways and 3 Musketeers bars.
In a television interview last Thursday, Mr. Toomey explained he chose to sit at the "candy desk," which is closest to the doors used by most senators to enter the floor.
"Pennsylvania is the confectionary capital of America," Mr. Toomey explained in a television interview last week.
"We've kept it very well stocked," he said. "It is a popular stopping-off place. It's of course available to all senators, irrespective of party."
The debates carried on well into the evening, as North Capitol Street clogged with traffic below the gallery's windows. Outside the Capitol, a fleet of black SUVs idled in the cold, waiting to whisk away the senators.
At its core, the impeachment proceeding was like any other trial: long hours demanding focus, a blend of memorable lines, key testimony and evidence, perhaps an interruption every now and then.
On Wednesday, an anti-abortion protester, well-known on Capitol Hill, the proceedings from the public gallery on Wednesday, shouting that Sen. Chuck "Schumer is the devil!" as he was escorted out by police.
The twists and turns of the trial will continue this week. And reporters will continue to be there to bring it to the American public.
Daniel Moore: dmoore@post-gazette.com, Twitter @PGdanielmoore

Is it a restaurant? A classroom? A vintage store? However you define it, Vessel &amp; Vine is terrific.

Información de publicación: Portland Press Herald ; Portland, Me. [Portland, Me]. 26 Jan 2020: F.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/is-restaurant-classroom-vintage-store-however-you/docview/2344608829/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Is+it+a+restaurant%3F+A+classroom%3F+A+vintage+store%3F+However+you+define+it%2C+Vessel+%26amp%3B+Vine+is+terrific.&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=F.6&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Portland+Press+Herald&amp;issn=2689-5900&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: My grandmother would have hated Vessel & Vine.
Always a routine eater with a particular penchant for boiled meats and canned vegetables, Grandma Ross probably wouldn't have had any idea what to make of chef/owner/proprietor Nikaline Iacono's short, spice-propelled menu of organic proteins, foraged ingredients and local produce.
Take her terrific sweet potato "hummus" ($7) - a dense, sesame-sprinkled spread that she whizzes up with tahini, lemon juice and freckles of sumac she finds growing wild not far from the restaurant's downtown Brunswick location. Scooped into an amber, Depression-glass dish and plated with cracker-thin slices of Standard Baking sourdough, the unconventional riff on the classic chickpea puree unspools threads of tartness in each bite.
Or the delightful Lacinato kale salad ($11), a teetering tower of nubbly greens and ribbons of maroon carrots from nearby Six River Farm. Glistening with maple-chile vinaigrette, the structure threatens to collapse at the first touch of your fork, sending quartered, maple-soy-pickled eggs tumbling down onto the plate.
My grandmother would have dismissed it all as "Wizard of Oz food," her favorite way to reject anything edible that was beyond her ken. And she would have been partly right - the streamlined menu at The Vine can feel a little fantastical, with dishes and cocktails that seem like they must have come to Iacono in a dream.
Under many (perhaps most) chefs, this eccentricity might spin out of control, but Iacono understands her flavors. Perhaps more importantly, she harnesses that same dangerously wobbly gyroscope that powers the food and beverage menus and unleashes it to animate the other facets of her business: a (mostly natural) wine shop, cocktail-making and cooking classes, vintage clothing and quirky barware.
"I see lots of places that are very linear, very focused. That's just not my personality. I have lots of interests and things I want to pursue. It's just my world in here," she said. "I don't really think of it as a restaurant. I want it to be a bar that has retail and really good food that you can piece together a meal at. People always want you to have more entrees, but I can't do that with my kitchen."
That's no mere excuse. Step around the mirrored, feather-garlanded bar and you'll discover that The Vine's back-of-house is more dormitory than diner, with equipment that totals two pressure cookers, an induction burner, a miniature crockpot and a toaster oven. No flat-top, no flame, no fryer.
These are constraints that would make the most resourceful chef blanch. But somehow, Iacono makes it all work seamlessly. She even bakes in her toaster oven, plating up squares of Southern-style (read: not very sweet) cornbread alongside a New Year's special to fill the "Comfort" slot on her menu: pressure-cooked pork with brothy black-eyed peas; delicate, smoky braised mustard greens and spinach leaves ($14). Nothing about this dish tips you off to the limitations of its creation.
"I find the idea of having all the ingredients and resources in the world to be overwhelming," she said. "The way I like to create my food and drink is to have restrictions and parameters."
So much so that she finds ways to introduce them into her beverage menu, where a do-it-yourself cocktail called "The Golden Ratio" ($12) challenges imbibers to mix and match components to create 256 drink possibilities from a preselected group of 12 base spirits, vermouths/aromatized wines and amari (herbal liqueurs that Iacono is so fond of, she offers an entire course about how to deploy them in cocktails).
Slyly, The Golden Ratio also teaches customers about equilibrating sweetness with bitterness and alcohol, using the 1:1:1 ratio of the Negroni as a starting point. "It's about understanding the classic principles, so that once you understand those rules, you'll know how to break them," Iacono said. "I want people to go home and play."
At times, The Vine's limitations ensnare the skeleton crew behind the scenes. On one recent visit, when there were just two staffers working (Iacono and a bartender), service lagged, leaving my two-top and the tables around me with empty water and wine glasses for long stretches.
I also wonder if the crush of 10-or-so new customers who suddenly overwhelmed the 30-something-seat dining room wasn't partly responsible for a carelessly overgenerous dose of salty black bean sauce on the mineral, toaster-oven-baked oysters (three for $12).
Impressively, it was the evening's only significant culinary misstep in a meal that yielded an unbelievably tender turmeric-spiced bread pudding, bathed in a pumpkin custard and topped with whipped cream goosed with a slug of Zirbenz Stone Pine liqueur ($8), as well as crisp, gremolata-topped "Fancy Toast" slathered with anchovy butter and sprinkled with teensy matchsticks of crunchy, winter-bitter Chioggia beet ($7).
My recent visit to The Vine also introduced me to one of my all-time favorite versions of dolma (rolled, ground-beef-stuffed cabbage leaves). Baked in a runny, aromatic sauce of sundried tomato and garlic, The Vine's dolma ($8) are spiced with Iacono's unique take on ras el hanout. Her reimagining of the Middle Eastern spice blend embroiders warming clove and paprika onto a scrim of rose petal, an inversion of the expected ras el hanout ratios, but one that seems to jolt the dish awake from a winter hibernation.
Grandma, if you're reading from above, I have a confession. I love The Vine for all the reasons that you probably would have despised it. But knowing how much you secretly enjoyed a seasonal tipple (and Depression glass), I'll toast to your memory with a cup of Iacono's The Fanciest Egg Nog Ever ($11), a custardy, saffron-scented cocktail made with natural rum, Fernet Gancia, spruce syrup and sweet sherry - the sort of Wizard of Oz concoction that even you would have begrudgingly adored.
Andrew Ross has written about food and dining in New York and the United Kingdom. He and his work have been featured on Martha Stewart Living Radio and in The New York Times. He is the recipient of three recent Critic's Awards from the Maine Press Association. Contact him at:
andrewross.maine@gmail.com
Twitter: @AndrewRossME

Louis C.K. isn't owed a second chance. He has to earn it.

Autor: Pan, Deanna. 

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 26 Jan 2020: R.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/louis-c-k-isnt-owed-second-chance-he-has-earn/docview/2344607674/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Louis+C.K.+isn%27t+owed+a+second+chance.+He+has+to+earn+it.&amp;author=Pan%2C+Deanna&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=R.5&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: In November 2017, three women told The New York Times that Louis C.K. had masturbated in front of them without their meaningful consent. Another woman told the newspaper C.K. had harassed her with a grotesque request to do the same. Rumors of his sexual misconduct with female performers and associates had dogged the comedian for years. The day after the Times report was published, he finally admitted, “These stories are true."
“I have spent my long and lucky career talking and saying anything I want," he wrote at the end of his public statement. “I will now step back and take a long time to listen." He expressed his remorse and regret. He did not apologize.
Nine months later, C.K. was apparently done listening. He made a surprise appearance at the Comedy Cellar in New York in August 2018, and returned to the popular club for several sets thereafter. In a performance attended by a Times reporter, he even cracked a few jokes about his “weird year" after getting “in trouble." He lamented that the fallout from his misdeeds cost him $35 million in a single hour.
Now C.K. is back on the stand-up circuit. He kicked off his tour in Richmond, Virginia, in November and will perform on April 4 in Boston, where he launched his once-ascendant comedy career. To his ardent supporters, C.K. is due for a comeback. As Hannah Giorgis pointed out in The Atlantic , his friends and fans have invoked the language of criminal justice in their defense of C.K.'s return to the stage. C.K. “served his time," the argument goes. For how much longer should he be punished?
But time alone does not absolve an abuser of his misbehavior. Second chances are earned, not owed. In his time out of the spotlight, C.K. pledged he would listen. Who did he listen to and what did he hear? What, if anything, did he learn?
If the reviews of his new stand-up routine are an indication, it would seem C.K. spent his self-imposed exile stewing in self-pity. “If he's looking for redemption, he's doing so privately," Los Angeles Times columnist Glenn Whipp, who saw C.K. shows in Richmond, and in Raleigh, North Carolina, generously surmised. Any mention of his sexual misconduct scandal is limited to jokes about his “pariah status," according to Whipp. “I had to go to Poland to do shows," C.K. moaned.
C.K. certainly paid a heavy price for his actions. In the aftermath of the Times expose, his management and publicist dumped him; FX, HBO, and Netflix cut ties with him; and the release of his new movie was canceled by its distributor.
But what about the ramifications suffered by the women C.K. betrayed? What price did they pay for his decision to exploit his power over them — and their choice to speak out?
In the years since C.K. stripped off his clothes and masturbated in front of comedians Dana Min Goodman and Julia Wolov in his hotel room at the 2002 U.S. Comedy Arts Festival, Goodman and Wolov “took themselves out of the running for the many projects" C.K.'s powerful manager, Dave Becky, was involved in, according to the Times, because by speaking openly to others about the incident, they heard they had run afoul of him. (Becky said he “never threatened anyone.") In an op-ed published in November by The Canadian Jewish News , Wolov wrote about the women “getting consistent hate mail from Louis C.K. supporters who tell them to kill themselves."
Comedian Rebecca Corry, who spoke to the Times about her encounter with C.K. on the set of a 2005 television pilot, wrote in an essay for New York Magazine' s Vulture that she has “received death threats, been berated, judged, ridiculed, dismissed, shamed, and attacked" since coming forward.
“Speaking out feels like standing in front of the world naked under fluorescent lights on a really bad day," Corry says in her essay. “I knew making myself so vulnerable would bring scrutiny from the outside, but my personal life has also been damaged by my decision to tell the truth."
The genius of C.K.'s comedy was his bracing and transgressive honesty — about his failings as a father and husband, for example, or his interminable self-loathing. His best work was rooted in empathy for others and for himself. What he has apparently failed to do since his abuses were made public is truly reckon with the harm he has caused. As many critics have acknowledged, C.K.'s failure to fully wrestle with his wrongdoing on stage in this post #MeToo era is a missed opportunity for a comic of his talent and stature. His self-centered riffs on his own fall from grace display a stunning lack of empathy for the women he hurt.
Louis C.K. is free to make a living however he chooses — with or without redemption. We are free not to laugh along.
______________
Deanna Pan is a reporter at The Boston Globe. Send comments to magazine@globe.com.

SCHIFF'S FOLLY THE SWAMP IS POISED TO RENEW THE NATION'S IRE

Autor: Dailey, Ruth Ann. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: E-3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/schiffs-folly-swamp-is-poised-renew-nations-ire/docview/2344607359/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=SCHIFF%27S+FOLLY+THE+SWAMP+IS+POISED+TO+RENEW+THE+NATION%27S+IRE&amp;author=Dailey%2C+Ruth+Ann&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E-3&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: As the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump opened in the U.S. Senate, Adam Schiff, visiting from the House of Representatives, implored the senators to honor the legacy of our wise, if flawed Founding Fathers.
He explained the gravity of impeachment and praised the founders for "insulat[ing] it, as best they could, from the crush of partisan politics."
He urged the Senate to provide a "fair trial" and to fulfill their duty "to the Constitution and to the rule of law."
Under all the lofty phrases and grave tone, what Mr. Schiff and his fellow Democrats seem to have forgotten is this: the fallout from the impeachment of Bill Clinton.
They've forgotten that if Americans smell a setup, if they see a cannon being rolled out when a rap on the knuckles would do, their sympathies shift to the accused.
The same national character that shaped our response to the Clinton impeachment will shape how we view this trial and its major players, including Mr. Schiff. Our shared character will also determine how we answer questions raised, perhaps accidentally, by his opening remarks:
Has the impeachment process actually been insulated from partisan politics, as he says the founders hoped? If not, who breached it?
What would a fair trial look like?
What outcome will do more to shore up confidence in our great republic?
Who has made the greater assault on our Constitution and the rule of law - Mr. Trump or his accusers?
Answers to some of these questions strike me as a draw. Each side has accused the other of putting a ridiculous spin on shifting "facts," hiding evidence and witnesses, unnecessarily redacting transcripts and so on.
A fair trial will require both sides to honor the same rules, to produce witnesses, to draw back the self-serving veil of secrecy, to allow the accused to face his accuser.
But as to whether the impeachment process has been insulated from partisan politics, the answer is a resounding no, and the responsibility for that breach lies with the Democrats - with Mr. Schiff himself.
Way back in October, even The Washington Post had to address Mr. Schiff's public lies about his committee not having had prior contact with the whistleblower, about not knowing who he was and more.
On Wednesday, even as Mr. Schiff opened the Senate trial, Paul Sperry's detailed report for RealClearInvestigations.com demonstrated anew, in appalling detail, how deeply entwined the whistleblower was with Mr. Schiff and his committee and how the "take-down" engine was already revving in 2017.
This reeks of bad faith, even to those of us who did not vote for Mr. Trump. And unless our partisanship is overwhelming, we Americans tend to judge people's actions instinctively and pretty fairly. We think the punishment should fit the crime, and we usually hold the person with more knowledge to a higher level of responsibility.
That's why public sentiment turned in favor of Mr. Clinton. He lied under oath, yes, but he was lying about having cheated on his wife and did so in response to questions that many people felt shouldn't have been asked in the first place.
Mr. Clinton won only 43% of the popular vote in 1992 and 49% in '96. Between those races, his party lost Congress to the "Republican Revolution." But after impeachment, his popularity soared and he left office in 2000 with Gallup approval ratings of 65%.
Similarly, only 46% voted for Mr. Trump in 2016, but in 2018 voters gave only the House back to the Democrats. Now the 2020 elections loom.
Mr. Schiff knows the law, the rules of Congress and probably the protocols of the presidency far better than Mr. Trump does. The president's supporters knew this when they voted for him; in fact, this is precisely why he won their support - because he wasn't part of the self-dealing D.C. swamp whose denizens practice to-the-death politics.
If Mr. Trump's voters still feel that way, and if independents and centrists feel he's been railroaded, the Democrats have already lost.
ruthanndailey@hotmail.com

WHEN THE OTHER AMERICA LIVES NEXT DOOR AN EMPATHETIC LOOK AT THE AMERICANS LEFT BEHIND

Autor: Halvonik, Steve. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 26 Jan 2020: E-5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-other-america-lives-next-door-empathetic/docview/2344607148/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=WHEN+THE+OTHER+AMERICA+LIVES+NEXT+DOOR+AN+EMPATHETIC+LOOK+AT+THE+AMERICANS+LEFT+BEHIND&amp;author=Halvonik%2C+Steve&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E-5&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Fourteen pages into "Tightrope: Americans Reaching for Hope," we meet Molly, a middle-aged woman who lives in a recreational vehicle in rural Oregon. She dropped out of school in the eighth grade and gave birth to a daughter at age 15. Molly never talked much about who the father was, inciting public scorn that she was "loose'' and "careless.'' Years later, Molly told her mother that her pregnancy was the result of a rape by her father. Her mother wasn't exactly surprised. "Your dad raped me, too, and that's how you got here,'' she replied.
With great compassion and perception, Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, the authors of "Tightrope," introduce us to dozens of Americans like Molly teetering on the financial precipice. Mr. Kristoff and Ms. WuDunn, who are married, shared the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for their coverage of China for The New York Times. They have co-authored four books including "Half the Sky,'' a chilling examination of the oppression of women and girls in Third World nations.
After years of using his Times op-ed column to highlight human-rights abuses and social injustices around the world, Mr. Kristof has turned his attention to the millions of Americans living in Third World conditions. The authors tell us that, despite a roaring stock market and historically low unemployment, many Americans are ailing:
* 2.1 million Americans addicted to opioids;
* 500,000 homeless;
* Half of U.S. jobs pay less than $15 an hour;
* Life expectancy in the United States ranks behind Chile (if Mississippi were a nation, it would rank second to last, tied with Mexico);
* The United States accounts for 25 percent of all the incarcerated people in the world.
"Tightrope'' looks at how we got here, and it offers suggestions for closing the misery gap.
Although the authors claim to have visited all 50 states, the most intimate stories are centered on Mr. Kristof's hometown, Yamhill, Ore., a farming hamlet (pop. 1,024) southwest of Portland. Mr. Kristof, 60, says that one-fourth of the kids who rode on his high school bus are dead from drugs, suicide, alcohol, obesity, reckless accidents and other pathologies. Many of those still living are struggling with dead-end jobs and drug and alcohol addictions.
Mr. Kristof is a self-described "progressive,'' but he doesn't sugarcoat his classmates' mistakes. He acknowledges that many of them shirked their personal responsibilities and were at least partly to blame for their miseries. Nevertheless, he argues, none of them suffered from any afflictions or setbacks that could not have been overcome with a helping hand. He fulminates against a society and government that undermined unions, slashed education funding and eliminated social programs - and then criminalized the ills they created through draconian prosecutions and sentencings.
The authors contrast Geneva Cooley, a 71-year-old African American woman who was sentenced to life in an Alabama prison for drug possession, with the Sackler family, which pocketed $13 billion through Purdue Pharma's legal slinging of OxyContin. It recalls the Bob Dylan line, "Steal a little and they throw you in jail, steal a lot and they make you king.''
Mr. Kristof and Ms. WuDunn mock conservatives such as former Speaker of the House Paul Ryan for saying that the poor should pull themselves up by their bootstraps. "To think that an obese, ninth-grade dropout with an outdated, blue-collar skill set could lift himself up by his bootstraps is magical thinking,'' they retort. The authors trace the roots of our affliction to the early 1970s and the rise of conservatism. They note that median wages for a majority of those without a college degree are lower today than in 1979, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics; that if the minimum wage had kept pace from 1968 to today, it would be $22 an hour; and that the average hourly wage of $22.65 in 2018 was lower than the $23.68 in 1973 (adjusted for inflation).
Mr. Kristof and Ms. WuDunn write that the federal government could ameliorate the suffering through high-quality early childhood programs, universal health coverage, "baby bonds'' to help build savings, and a right to work. Anticipating conservative pushback, they claim that their proposals could all be paid for simply by returning to 1990s-level tax rates. "The United States has chosen policies over the last half century that have resulted in higher levels of homelessness, overdose deaths, crime and inequality - and now it's time to make a different choice,'' the authors conclude. Readers mourning the absence of empathy in the public square should grab a copy of "Tightrope: Americans Reaching for Hope.''
Steve Halvonik, a former Post-Gazette reporter and editor, teaches journalism at Point Park University.

Violinist finds 'infinite possibilities' in Bach's complete cello suites

Autor: Weininger, David. 

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 26 Jan 2020: N.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/violinist-finds-infinite-possibilities-bachs/docview/2344606923/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Violinist+finds+%27infinite+possibilities%27+in+Bach%27s+complete+cello+suites&amp;author=Weininger%2C+David&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=N.3&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: JOHNNY GANDELSMAN
Presented by the MIT Center for Art, Science & Technology. At Kresge Auditorium, MIT. Feb. 8, 7 p.m. www.eventbrite.com
January 2015. The violinist Johnny Gandelsman — Moscow-born, New York-based, and a member of such restlessly curious groups as the Silk Road Ensemble and the string quartet Brooklyn Rider — is on the small stage of MIT's Killian Hall. He has just finished playing Bach's complete sonatas and partitas, the summit of the solo violin repertoire, to an enthusiastic audience that fills the room. The ovation is well earned, as Gandelsman's performance is notable for the supple touch he brings to music that violinists often swath in layers of profundity. Even in the epic chaconne movement of the D-minor partita he emphasizes the music's dance roots.
Among the most enthused audience members is Gandelsman's Silk Road bandmate, Yo-Yo Ma. Ma is, in fact, loudly clamoring for an encore. With a sly smile, the violinist obliges by playing the first bar of Bach's Third Cello Suite. Lasting just a few seconds, it is both a subtle inside joke between friends and a perfect capstone to the evening.
But there's another, slightly fanciful, way to see that brief encore: as the origin of Gandelsman's latest project: all six of the Bach cello suites, transcribed for violin. His recording of this slice of the Bach solo string repertoire is slated for release on his own label (In a Circle Records) on Feb. 7; the next evening, he returns to MIT to perform all the suites, this time in the larger Kresge Auditorium. Might that brief encore half a decade ago — a salute to a cellist whose name has become almost synonymous with the Bach suites — have been the catalyst for this new undertaking?
Alas, the truth rarely fits into our stories as we might wish it would. In a recent e-mail exchange, Gandelsman explained that the MIT concert came at the beginning of his experience performing the sonatas and partitas, some time before he began thinking about the cello suites. It was only after performing them about 30 times, he wrote, that he realized that “I wasn't quite ready to stop working on Bach's music."
Fair enough. But why, you might ask, did Gandelsman feel compelled to make the suites, which have never lacked performance opportunities by cellists themselves for the past several decades, part of his repertoire?
It was actually a different cellist, Anner Bylsma, who provided the inspiration. Bylsma, a titan in the period instrument world who died last year at 85, and his wife, violinist Vera Beths, hosted Gandelsman at their home in Amsterdam a few times. This was a pilgrimage many musicians have made — to play for the master cellist and immerse themselves in Bach's world.
“I loved every moment spent in that house," Gandelsman wrote. “Anner's continuous and evolving learning of those pieces was infectious." During one visit, he noticed that one of Bylsma's books on the suites contained a transcription for violin. “It's possible that he intended it to be for practice purposes only, but after a while I thought, why not?"
Listening to Gandelsman's forthcoming recording, one recognizes up front the grace and agility that informed his interpretation of the sonatas and partitas. His account of the suites seems, if anything, even lighter and more dance-worthy. In part that's because of the violin's lighter timbre and his use of a lighter bow and gut strings for three of the violin's four strings. (For the sixth suite, which Bach is believed to have written for a five-string instrument, Gandelsman uses a five-string violin he found at an instrument shop in Queens.) But there's a new ingredient as well: his playing of the suites has an almost improvisatory sense of freedom, and some of the movements sound distinctly like folk music.
This was no accident. In fact, Gandelsman mentioned that over the last few years he's seen more and more commonalities between Baroque and folk musics. For the suites, he tried to learn the music by ear rather than by studying the score, the opposite of how he approached the sonatas and partitas. Doing so, he came to see in the suites “the implication for infinite possibilities, the way an incredible improviser can find endless variation within the simplest form."
One of his favorite improvisers is the Irish fiddler Martin Hayes, with whom Brooklyn Rider recently recorded an album. At one point in the e-mail exchange, Gandelsman described the suites as a place where all these currents of influence came together in a vision of music that balanced tradition, freedom, and the wonder of discovery.
“Like Bach, Martin is an incredible improviser, creating endless variation in expression," he wrote. “Similar to Anner's process, Martin's playing has the humble joy of a scientist's pursuit, finding out what else might be in there, what layers might still be hiding. Improvisation is not something I'm very comfortable with, but my goal is to get to a place where I can feel like what's happening in terms of bowings and phrasing is created on the spot."
David Weininger can be reached at globeclassicalnotes@gmail.com. Follow him on Twitter @davidgweininger.

Role models

Autor: Goldman, Alison. 

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 26 Jan 2020: B.12.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/role-models/docview/2344606910/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Role+models%3A+Newton-raised+actress+Hari+Nef+joins+Aly+Raisman+in+Aerie%27s+self-love+campaign&amp;author=Goldman%2C+Alison&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.12&amp;date=2020-01-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Since 2014, clothing brand Aerie has featured real women in unretouched photos as part of its body positivity-focused #AerieREAL campaign. Beginning in 2016, several celebrities and influencers — including Olympic gold medal-winning gymnast and Needham native Aly Raisman — have signed on as #AerieREAL Role Models to “spread the brand's mission to love your real self — inside and out," according to the brand.
On Thursday, eight more Role Models joined the fold, among them Newton's Hari Nef , who's an actress, activist, and, per The New York Times, the first transgender model to be represented worldwide by IMG.
All of the 2020 Role Models — which also include actresses Lana Condor (“To All the Boys I've Loved Before") and Beanie Feldstein (“Booksmart") — chose a quick statement to explain what they hope to convey through their work on the campaign; Nef “encourages others to question and oppose the status quo — with empathy!"
The “Transparent" actress — who said she swaps stories with Raisman about growing up in Boston suburbs — told the Globe she wishes something like the #AerieREAL campaign had existed when she was a Boston-area teenager.
“When I was in high school at Newton South High School, I used to walk around with printouts of those skinny runway models in my folder because I wanted to look like them," said Nef, 27. “And somehow I kind of evolved into a version of one of them, but it was by sheer force of will. And I was never that tall, and I was never that thin. But I was welcomed in this industry that, at just the moment that I was ready, coincidentally and thank God, they were willing and ready to welcome something different. And I feel lucky to have been that thing, but I still feel like there's a long way to go in this industry of looking, I think, just beyond the surface, beyond the kind of boxes one ticks, whether that box aligns with the historic norm or opposing the status quo — that's become a box unto itself."
Nef said she feels “great" about Aerie's lack of retouching, but that wasn't always the case. Previously as a model, she was grateful for fashion industry retouchers.
“They would give me new faces, new bodies, and I would thank them for it, because I felt like they were doing me a favor," she said. “And at the time, that was how I was thinking about myself. I don't feel that way anymore. And I'm excited to be a part of this imagery that's going to be widely circulated that — I've got my hair in, and I've got my makeup on, and I know I look good, but not a single thing on my body has been touched by a blur tool, or, nothing's been nipped, nothing's been tucked. It's just me."
Nef has a bunch of work on her 2020 docket, including a “fun, little, weird, delicious television project dropping at some point this year as part of an anthology," as well as some screenwriting projects she's “been working [on] rather sneakily and under the radar for the past couple of years." She said she'll also be rolling out more events and collaborations with Aerie in the coming months.
Rounding out the 2020 class of Role Models are sustainability activist Manuela Barón , scientist and entrepreneur Keiana Cavé , DJ and wellness advocate Tiff McFierce , Tony Award-winning performer Ali Stroker , Smile On Me founder Dre Thomas , and previous Role Models Raisman, YouTuber and motivational speaker Molly Burke , Paralympic gold medal-winning snowboarder Brenna Huckaby , podcast host Jenna Kutcher , and body-positive model and activist Iskra Lawrence .
ALISON GOLDMAN
@alisongoldman alisonmgoldman.com .
