Coronavirus death toll rises to 56 in China as US diplomats prepare to leave Wuhan

Autor: Stanglin, Doug. 

Información de publicación: USA Today (Online) ; Arlington [Arlington]. 25 Jan 2020.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/coronavirus-death-toll-rises-56-china-as-us/docview/2344549553/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: As the US closed its Wuhan consulate, Chinese President Xi Jingping warned of a "grave situation" in the rapid spread of the coronavirus

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Coronavirus+death+toll+rises+to+56+in+China+as+US+diplomats+prepare+to+leave+Wuhan&amp;author=Stanglin%2C+Doug&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=USA+Today+%28Online%29&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: As the U. S. closed its consulate in Wuhan and prepared to extract all its diplomats, Chinese President Xi Jinping warned Saturday of a "grave situation" in the rapid spread of the coronavirus that has claimed 56 lives.
The virus, which broke out in Wuhan last month, has infected at least 1,975 people in at least 29 provinces and cities and killed 56 people in China, according to the National Health Commission.
The figures reported Sunday morning cover the previous 24 hours and mark an increase of 15 deaths and 688 cases.
The government also reported five cases in Hong Kong, two in Macao and three in Taiwan. Small numbers of cases have been found in Thailand, Japan, South Korea, the U. S. , Vietnam, Singapore, Malaysia, Nepal, France and Australia.
Among the victims is Liang Wudong, a 62-year-old doctor at Hubei Xinhua Hospital who died Saturday after treating patients in Wuhan, according to the state-run Global Television Network.
A hospital in Toronto confirmed Saturday that it is treating a patient with the deadly virus, Canada’s first.
A second case in the U. S. was confirmed Friday in Chicago, along with three cases in France. There have been no deaths outside of China.
The U. S. State Department arranged a charter flight for Tuesday to bring out all its diplomats and other U. S. citizens after temporarily closing the Wuhan consulate, the Associated Press reported. A notice Sunday from the embassy in Beijing said there would be limited capacity to transport U. S. citizens on the flight that will proceed directly to San Francisco.
The reports followed a State Department notice on its website that all essential personnel had been ordered to leave the city of 11 million.
'Everything now is experimental. ': Here's how doctors are treating coronavirus
Xi addressed the issue Saturday at a special Communist party meeting where he called for stepped up moves to tackle the accelerating crisis.
“Confronted with the grave situation of this accelerating spread of pneumonia from infections with the novel coronavirus, we must step up the centralized and united leadership under the party central” leadership, Xi said.
A report issued from the meeting said that Hubei province, where Wuhan is located, "must make containment and control of the epidemic its top most priority, adopting even stricter measures to prevent it expanding within and spreading outward. ”
China has already halted all train, plane and other transportation links to the city, which has ordered a ban on all downtown vehicle traffic beginning at midnight Saturday, state media reported.
Only authorized vehicles to carry supplies and for other needs would be permitted after that, the reports said.
The city said it will assign 6,000 taxis to different neighborhoods, under the management of local resident committees, to help people get around if they need to, the state-owned English-language China Daily newspaper said.
Wuhan outbreak: Something far deadlier than the coronavirus lurks near you, right here in America
Elsewhere, the latest U. S. victim, a Chicago woman, returned Jan. 13 from Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, and began experiencing symptoms a few days after arriving home, said Dr. Allison Arwady, commissioner of the Chicago Department of Public Health.
The 60-year-old woman called her doctor after symptoms arose. She was treated at St. Alexius in Hoffman Estates and placed in isolation, health officials said. Further testing confirmed the virus.
Arwady said the woman is "clinically doing well and in stable condition. " She did not have extended contact with anyone outside of her home, attend a large public gathering or use public transportation, Arwady said.
The woman was not symptomatic while flying, and Arwady told reporters at a Chicago news conference on Friday, "The CDC does not believe that, in the time before symptoms develop, the patients are able to be contagious. "
In Paris, the lead doctor treating two hospital patients for the new virus said Saturday that the illness appears less serious than comparable outbreaks of the past and that the chance of a European epidemic appears weak at this stage.
French officials on Friday reported three confirmed cases of the newly identified coronavirus in France, the first ones in Europe. The third patient is at a hospital in Bordeaux.
Dr. Yazdan Yazdanpaneh, a leading French expert who heads Bichat’s infectious diseases unit, said that cases imported from China were “not a surprise” and that France had prepared, including by developing a test that provides rapid results for suspected cases.
While most cases have centered in China, an increasing number of cases have been confirmed in other places, including South Korea, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, Macao, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam. Australia and Malaysia reported their first cases Saturday and Japan reported its third.
As the crisis increased, local Chinese authorities rushed to build a 1,000-bed hospital in six days to treat the growing number of patients. Authorities announced Saturday that 658 patients were being treated for the virus and 57 were critically ill, Reuters reports.
The state-run Global Television Network reported Saturday that the health commission was sending six groups of 1,230 medical staff to Wuhan, In addition, 450 military doctors, some with experience fighting the SARS and Ebola viruses, were sent to the city Friday.
The Xinhua news agency reported that additional medical supplies were being rushed to the city, including 14,000 protective suits and 110,000 pairs of gloves from the central medical reserves as well as masks and goggles.
The virus has caused major public upheaval, with the government shutting down public transportation for roughly 36 million people in 13 cities in central China and major cities canceling events tied to the Lunar New Year celebration, a busy time for travel.
Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said all direct flights and trains form Wuhan would be blocked and that all schools would be closed in the city until Feb. 17.
Beijing's Forbidden City, Shanghai Disneyland and sections of the Great Wall have also closed.
Rapidly-spreading respiratory virus: Drugmakers are hustling to make a coronavirus vaccine
What is coronavirus?
Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to pneumonia. Common signs of infection include fever, cough, shortness of breath and breathing difficulties. In more severe cases, infection can cause severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and death.
Health officials said the virus, which probably spreads through tiny droplets when a person coughs or sneezes, is low-risk. Officials urged people to take the usual cold and flu season precaution: frequent hand washing, covering your mouth when coughing or sneezing and staying home when you don't feel well.
"These illnesses can pop up anywhere," said Trish Perl, chief of infectious diseases at UT Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas. "This is a dynamic situation that can dramatically change from day to day. "
Coronaviruses are zoonotic, meaning they are transmitted between animals and people. Many of the initial cases were linked to a seafood and meat market in Wuhan. Chinese health officials, which first reported the cases last month, said human-to-human transmission has been confirmed.
Contributing: Ryan Miller, Grace Hauck, Nicholas Wu, John Bacon, Ken Alltucker and Lindsay Schnell, USA TODAY; The Associated Press.

____________________________________________________________

Gender shouldn't be presidential qualification

Autor: Balusik, Christopher. 

Información de publicación: The Advocate ; Newark, Ohio [Newark, Ohio]. 25 Jan 2020: C.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/gender-shouldnt-be-presidential-qualification/docview/2344516214/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Gender+shouldn%27t+be+presidential+qualification&amp;author=Balusik%2C+Christopher&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.5&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Advocate&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Yes, a woman can be elected president of the United States. It's time to put that non-issue behind us.
As Bernie Sanders pointed out in the Democratic debate in Iowa Jan. 14, "Hillary Clinton won the popular vote by 3 million votes."
Everywhere else, that would have been enough. Regrettably, the United States is burdened with an anachronism called the Electoral College, reflecting the mistrust of small states for large ones.
Just 77,000 more votes in three key states made the difference between a President Clinton and a President Trump four years ago; between having a First Man or a First Lady in the White House.
It used to be said that a Roman Catholic couldn't be elected president. Then John F. Kennedy was.
Divorce was assumed to be a disqualification. Ronald Reagan disproved that. Race was the next frontier. Then Barack Obama was elected.
In the current campaign, Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is a formidable contender. She'd be even stronger if she weren't contending with Sanders for the same voters. She scored points in the Des Moines debate by observing that the men on the stage had collectively lost 10 elections while she and Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota were undefeated.
That Klobuchar remains in a dwindling field reflects her potential as the moderate alternative to Sanders or Warren if Joe Biden doesn't do well in the early caucus and primary states.
Male machismo and misogyny are hardly unique to the United States. Yet 59 other nations, spanning the world and every region and ethnicity, have had women as heads of government. Why hasn't it happened here?
One reason is that it took time to break the glass ceilings in Congress, state capitals and the vice presidency, which are the traditional proving grounds for presidential prospects.
Since women were enfranchised 101 years ago, only five Democratic women and two Republicans have attained enough political exposure and stature to be taken seriously as candidates in the two major parties. Margaret Chase Smith of Maine was the first, opposing Barry Goldwater for the 1964 GOP nomination. Clinton gave Obama strong competition in 2008 before winning the nomination eight years later.
The Democratic debates should have put to rest the gender issue. As New York Times columnist Frank Bruni observed, questions could also be raised over age — Biden is 77 and Sanders is 78 — and over Pete Buttigieg's identity as a gay man with a male spouse.
"Doesn't that make them risky nominees in their own ways?" Bruni wrote. "If Warren and Klobuchar were less polite and restrained, they might have said so last night. Instead they just turned in debate performances that showed just how commanding women are."
So, can a woman be elected president?
Yes.
So can a man.
There is no material difference.
What really matters is who is qualified, competent and trustworthy.
– The (South Florida) Sun-Sentinel
CREDIT: Christopher Balusik

Materia: Debates; Presidents; Political campaigns; Women

Tech execs becoming victims of swatting attacks, police say

Autor: Frenkel, Sheera. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 25 Jan 2020: 9.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/tech-execs-becoming-victims-swatting-attacks/docview/2344515870/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Tech+execs+becoming+victims+of+swatting+attacks%2C+police+say&amp;author=Frenkel%2C+Sheera&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=9&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: Over the first week of November, the police in San Francisco and New York responded to a series of telephone calls claiming that hostages were being held in the homes of Adam Mosseri, a senior Facebook executive.
The calls appeared to be coming from inside the homes.
Officers arrived in force and barricaded the streets outside. Twice.
But after tense, hourslong standoffs, they realized the calls were hoaxes. There were no hostages, and no one in the homes had called the police.
Mosseri is one of a number of tech executives who have been targeted recently in so-called swatting incidents. Swatting is online lingo used to describe when people call the police with false reports of a violent crime of some sort inside a home, hoping to persuade them to send a SWAT team.
These episodes have become more common in communities rich with tech companies and their billionaire executives, like the Bay Area and Seattle, according to six police departments contacted by The New York Times.
Exact numbers are unclear, police say, because there is no central repository of information for these sorts of attacks.
But as online discourse has become more combative and more personal, some in the industry aren't surprised that tech executives -- the people who decide what is posted on social media and who is barred from it -- have become regular targets.
Swattings have spiked at Facebook in particular, according to local police departments and security officials at the company, which in recent years has cracked down on false accounts, threatening language and other types of content that violates its rules. They spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity surrounding the attacks.
Mosseri declined to comment, and a Facebook spokesman, Anthony Harrison, said in a statement that "because these things deal with security matters and our employees, we are unable to comment."
The attacks have been aided by forums that have sprung up both on the public internet and on the camouflaged sites of the so-called dark web. These forums name thousands of people, from high-ranking executives to their extended families, who could be targets, providing cellphone numbers, home addresses and other information. Some even discuss techniques that can be used -- like cheap, online technology that can spoof a phone number and make the police believe a 911 call is coming from a target's home.
In the eight months since one online forum was started, nearly 3,000 people have joined.
"Who should we do next?" read one message on the forum last month. The responses included gun emojis -- the symbol, in swatting forums, for an attack in which the police were successfully called to the target's home. Many of the responses were laced with profanity, as well as suggestions for ex-girlfriends who should be swatted.
One forum names at least two dozen Facebook employees as potential targets. They range from executives to product engineers. Some forum participants said that they had been barred from Facebook or Instagram, and that Facebook employees were fair game because they "think they are god."
Swatting started in the combative world of online gaming. It was a way to terrorize someone more famous, get even with a rival or retaliate against someone with different political views.
Provoking a heavily armed police response presents obvious risks. Last year, a 26-year-old California man was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison for calling in dozens of fake emergency calls, including one that led to the fatal police shooting of Andrew Finch, a Kansas resident.
CAPTION: Photo: Adam Mosseri, a senior Facebook executive, is one of a number of tech executive targeted in swatting incidents. RICKY RHODES/THE NEW YORK TIMES 2019
CREDIT: By Sheera Frenkel, The New York Times

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Información de publicación: Arizona Republic ; Phoenix, Ariz. [Phoenix, Ariz]. 25 Jan 2020: Z.89.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/letters-editor/docview/2344515840/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=LETTERS+TO+THE+EDITOR%3A+HOA+HAS+A+DARK+HEART&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=Z.89&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: HOA's are entitled to have and enforce certain rules. But shouldn't they also be expected to show some compassion for a tragically orphaned teen? ("HOA wants to kick orphaned teen out of grandparents' house," Jan. 15).
Would they force him to live on the streets? Or perhaps worse, be sentenced to years in the foster care system?
I wonder if any HOA board member would force his own grandchild out of the only family home left to him!
K. D. Myrick, Phoenix
Not another stadium? Thank you for reporting on the Akimel 7 development project earlier this week. I was surprised to learn that tax credits are going to a project that includes plans for a new professional sports arena.
The article hints that the new arena may lure the Coyotes or Diamondbacks to the East Valley. That move would leave a vacant stadium downtown or in Glendale.
Arizona Veterans Memorial Coliseum is a near-vacant arena that is both close to downtown and on the west side. Since we already have a near-vacant stadium serving those areas, tax incentives should not be used to create another.
Paul Franckowiak, Laveen
Classless leader in high-class city I'm a proud resident of Scottsdale, and we are touted as a high-class city. On the other hand, it's confounding why we continue to elect a low-class politician like Jay Lawrence — an admitted bigot, and purveyor of conspiracies?
Seems to me to be very low standards for an electorate I know is well educated and looking for the best for our city and state.
Jeff Jameson, Scottsdale
Trust schools with sex ed? I am skeptical of public schools teaching sex education. After all, these are the people that can't seem to properly teach their mandated curriculum of English, science and math. And you want to entrust them with sex education?
Kathy Diekelman, Chandler
Virtue signaling at APS It's wonderful that APS plans on becoming carbon free by 2050 (even though they admit the technology to do that doesn't exist). However, APS's goal will be meaningless virtue signaling unless APS and the rest of us become China Free.
China is the worst climate criminal and, as the New York Times recently reported, is growing its coal-burning, climate changing CO2 footprint at home and abroad.
As long as APS and the rest of us keep buying products produced by China or unless China stops its evil ways (don't count on that), Arizona and America won't be carbon free.
Jim McManus, Phoenix
What would Flake and McCain do? What if Senators Jeff Flake and John McCain were still our representatives during Trump's Senate impeachment trial? What would we Arizonans be facing?
They both butted heads with the president and perhaps would have sided with the facts instead of ignoring the truth. Nixon resigned not long after he'd lost the support of Arizona Sen. Barry Goldwater and Rep. John Rhodes.
Country over party is sadly no more.
Armando Arvizu, Phoenix

____________________________________________________________

Spoiler alert? Not here. Film critic's estate and RIT settle suit, but hide details

Autor: Craig, Gary. 

Información de publicación: Rochester Democrat and Chronicle ; Rochester, N.Y. [Rochester, N.Y]. 25 Jan 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/spoiler-alert-not-here-film-critics-estate-rit/docview/2344514301/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Spoiler+alert%3F+Not+here.+Film+critic%27s+estate+and+RIT+settle+suit%2C+but+hide+details&amp;author=Craig%2C+Gary&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Rochester+Democrat+and+Chronicle&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: "All I can say is that the case has been settled."
Ken Norwick
Attorney for the Kauffmann estate
If the lawsuit from the estate of the late movie critic Stanley Kauffmann against the Rochester Institute of Technology were a film, Kauffmann likely would have panned it.
Sure, there were some intriguing characters — including a serial plagiarist who duped a college press — and some twists and turns, with the lawsuit once killed (or, in legal terms, dismissed) by a judge, only to be raised from the dead by an appellate court. Imagine Shattered Glass meets Night of the Living Dead.
The denouement, however, would surely get mixed reviews — especially were the critic the occasionally droll but always trenchant Kauffman.
In short, the federal copyright lawsuit settled this month, and no one is saying on what terms, whether there was money involved, and, if the latter, how much. The Sopranos ended with more clarity.
"All I can say is that the case has been settled," Ken Norwick, the attorney for the Kauffmann estate, said in an email. RIT spokeswoman Ellen Rosen also declined comment.
Kauffmann, who died in 2013, was a film critic for The New Republic for 50 years. He was a respected contrarian who rarely fell into the fold with his fellow cinephile scribes. (As The New York Times noted upon Kauffmann's death, he called Casablanca "a slushy romance.")
In 2017 Kauffmann's estate sued the college and RIT Press, which had published a volume of Kauffmann's writings. That book, The Millennial Critic: Stanley Kauffmann on Film 1999 - 2009, was edited by Robert "Bert" Cardullo, himself a former film critic and a collegiate teacher of criticism.
Cardullo, who turned out to have a history of plagiarism, did not have permission from the estate to sell or publish the essays, the 2017 lawsuit claimed. RIT Press, after learning of possible problems, halted publication of the book and tried to recall copies that had been sold.
In 2018, a federal judge tossed out the lawsuit, ruling that The New Republic, and not the Kauffmann estate, owned the rights to the reviews and essays. Last year, a federal appellate court determined that the judge's ruling was in error, and the lawsuit was revived.
Earlier this month, the lawsuit quietly settled — with, to date, no public record of the terms of the resolution.
So, since the legal imbroglio has provided no resolution for public access, let's instead end with some of Kauffmann's more controversial takes from his time at The New Republic:
On the original Star Wars: "About the dialogue there's nothing to be said. In fact the dialogue itself can hardly be said: it sticks in the actors' mouths like peanut butter."
On Forrest Gump: "I can't see how people with low I.Q.s or those who love them are in any way comforted by all this hogwash. I can easily see how such people might be offended by its smug unreality."
On Jaws: "The only performer worth mentioning is Robert Shaw as the old pro and I mention him only to hope that he is getting rich. This good actor certainly ought to get something out of all the non-acting he's doing these days."
Contact Gary Craig at gcraig@gannett.com or at 585-258-2479. Follow him on Twitter at gcraig1.
"All I can say is that the case has been settled."
Ken Norwick
Attorney for the Kauffmann estate
CREDIT: Gary Craig

Autor: Frenkel, Sheera.

Envelope, please: 2020's children's book awards

Información de publicación: Arizona Republic ; Phoenix, Ariz. [Phoenix, Ariz]. 25 Jan 2020: Z.1_1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/envelope-please-2020s-childrens-book-awards/docview/2344510867/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Envelope%2C+please%3A+2020%27s+children%27s+book+awards&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=Z.1_1&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Get ready to clap or groan or throw your hands up and say, "Huh?"
Why? Because very soon, the American Library Association will announce the Youth Media Awards. View the winners live on Monday, Jan. 27, starting at 6 a.m. Arizona time at ala.unikron.com
The ALA Youth Media Awards honors the year's best original and creative work in children's literature, including the prestigious Newbery, Caldecott, Printz and Coretta Scott King awards.
To make the 2020 decisions, committees composed of librarians and other literature and media experts spent hours reading, reviewing, and discussing books. They were not alone! A quick internet search displayed numerous hearty deliberations. Everyone from teachers to parents to booksellers had opinions.
Oh, but what about children? Certainly, they have opinions. Perhaps surprisingly, they are NOT a part of the decision making process. So, before the announcements are made, let's review criteria for the two oldest awards: The John Newbery and the Randolph J. Caldecott.
According to the Association for Library Services for Children, the Newbery Medal is awarded annually for the most distinguished American children's book published in the United States in English during the previous year.
The idea was proposed on June 22, 1921, by Frederic G. Melcher, who suggested it be named for 18th-century English bookseller John Newbery. When approved, the Newbery Award became the first children's book award in the world.
The committee that reviews the books for any given year looks for both literary quality and superior presentation for children. The ALA further states that the author is a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. Along with the winner, honor books are announced.
The ALA indicates that the Caldecott Medal is awarded to the artist of the "most distinguished American picture book for children published in the United States during the preceding year." When you read any Caldecott winner, remember the award is for illustration, not story. Although, the words must be worthy of the illustrations.
As with the Newbery Award, the artist must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. Recently, Leonard S. Marcus, distinguished American author and children's literature expert, wrote an op-ed in the New York Times recommending that the Caldecott receive a makeover, an international one! He proposes abolishing the rule that candidates must be American.
According to Marcus, in 1938, when the ALA introduced the Caldecott, the United States was still a "cultural stepchild of Europe." At that time, British picture books like "The Adventures of Peter Rabbit" by Beatrix Potter had a stronghold on American children. By limiting Caldecott eligibility to American citizens and permanent residents, the ALA hoped to spark American creativity in illustration, just as they had done for the literary Newbery Award over a decade earlier.
Marcus insists that illustrations in picture books with their "beguiling cultural inflection" provide children with a universal language and the "American only" metric is pointless in today's world. Marcus is well respected, but redesigning the Caldecott Medal for worldwide eligibility is the sole decision of the ALA.
Presently, the Caldecott Medal remains uniquely American. This year, like previous years, the suspense and excitement of the announcement will bubble over in homes, libraries and schools. I hope you watch the unveiling ceremony!
Anita N. Voelker, Ph.D., is a children's book enthusiast, reading specialist, and scholar who writes occasionally for The Arizona Republic. Contact her at avoelker51@cox.net

Biden a stronger contender than many made him out to be OP-ED

Autor: David Brooks David Brooks is an opinion columnist for The New York Times. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 25 Jan 2020: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/biden-stronger-contender-than-many-made-him-out/docview/2344508125/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Biden+a+stronger+contender+than+many+made+him+out+to+be+OP-ED&amp;author=David+Brooks+David+Brooks+is+an+opinion+columnist+for+The+New+York+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: It was yet another epic failure of political punditry. Go back to the early months of Joe Biden's presidential campaign and read what the consultants and commentators were saying about him: His support is just name recognition; he'll fade! He's too old! He's running a zombie campaign! The party has moved left and he's out of touch! He voted for the crime bill!
Almost everybody was bearish on Joe. But now look where we are, weeks from actual voting. If the polls are to be believed, Biden will win Iowa; he'll come in second in New Hampshire; he will easily win Nevada; he will dominate in South Carolina. He's now tied for the lead in California, and he's way ahead in Texas.
I don't know if he'll win the nomination (both he and Bernie Sanders look strong), but this is not where a lot of people six months ago thought we'd be.
It's the 947th consecutive sign that we in the coastal chattering classes have not cured our insularity problem. It's the 947th case in which we see that every second you spend on Twitter detracts from your knowledge of American politics and that the only cure to this insularity disease is constant travel and interviewing, close attention to state and local data and raw abject humility about the fact that the attitudes and academic degrees that you think make you clever are actually the attitudes and academic degrees that separate you from the real texture of American life.
Biden didn't just luck into this. He and his team grasped six truths:
* Understand the year you are running in. Sanders and Elizabeth Warren are running the same basic campaign they would have run in 2012 or 2016. Biden's campaign is completely focused on the central problem of 2020: that Donald Trump is a steaming hot mess in the middle of national life.
Biden has fixated his campaign on the Trump problem and fighting for the soul of America. Nearly twice as many Democrats say it's more important to beat Trump than to have a candidate with whom they agree on all issues.
* Understand your party's core challenge. All around the world, parties on the left are losing because they have lost touch with the working class. These parties think they can reconnect with that class by swinging even further left. But Jeremy Corbyn in Britain and Bernie Sanders here are a doctoral student's idea of a working-class candidate, not an actual working person's idea of one.
Biden has criticized his own party for losing touch with this class. He emerged from it, is focusing his attention on it and is winning support from it.
* Moderates are still powerful. The Democratic Party is moving left, but about half of Democrats still say they are moderate or conservative. No candidate has ever won a nomination without strong support from these voters, while college-town candidates - Howard Dean, Gary Hart - tend to falter. In every presidential general election that Democrats have won since 1988, they carried moderates by more than 12 percentage points. In every race they have lost, they failed to do that. Biden kept his moderate credentials when many other candidates saw A.O.C. on Twitter and decided to move left.
* Many Democrats resent their own elites. There is a quiet tension between Democrats who wield cultural power and those who don't. The former are active on social media and clobber the latter - people who say or write the "wrong" thing.
The non-elites tend to feel judged and looked down on by the self-appointed savior class. "Politically correct" has become the phrase people use to define those who use cultural power to enforce ideological conformity. Seventy percent of Democrats who are not on social media say political correctness is a big problem. These are people silently but vehemently reacting against this social reign of terror. Biden communicates affection, not judgment; acceptance, not expulsion.
* Have a better theory of social change. Sanders and Warren imagine they can rally movements of progressive supermajorities to transform American politics. The reality is that if they are elected we'll be stuck with the same 42%-to-42% stagnant political war we have now.
Biden starts with the understanding that we are a closely divided nation. He understands the elemental fact that if you want to pass laws you have to go through Congress. As Damon Linker pointed out recently in The Week, Biden's argument is that a center-left congressional coalition is the best we can do under present circumstances. That's a more realistic theory of change. A beloved legislator like Biden is more likely to transform the political landscape than a down-the-line progressive.
* Connection. Connection. Connection. Many candidates pound the podium and lecture at their rallies. It's the big leader onstage and the passionate mass of followers down below. Nobody makes an individual connection as well as Biden. In a time when people feel exhausted, isolated and alienated, a candidate who seems normal and emotionally relatable is going to have a lot of appeal.
The ironic fact is that the candidate who can be vulnerable has a surprising power.
David Brooks is an opinion columnist for The New York Times.
Caption: Democratic presidential candidate former Vice President Joe Biden speaks at a campaign event on Wednesday at the North Iowa Events Center in Mason City, Iowa.
John Locher/AP

Hail to the beach: A history of presidents visiting Cape May County

Autor: Berkery, Sheri. 

Información de publicación: Daily Journal ; Vineland, N.J. [Vineland, N.J]. 25 Jan 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hail-beach-history-presidents-visiting-cape-may/docview/2344508122/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Hail+to+the+beach%3A+A+history+of+presidents+visiting+Cape+May+County&amp;author=Berkery%2C+Sheri&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: When President Donald Trump holds a rally in Wildwood on Jan. 28, he will be surrounded by cellphones, webcams and giant screens.
That wasn't the case the last time a president visited Cape May County.
But then again, it was the 1890s.
Benjamin Harrison was reportedly the most recent presidential visitor in the county that will host Trump next week.
Trump will be the first sitting president in Wildwood — a location chosen because it's in the district of U.S. Rep Jeff Van Drew, who recently switched to the Republican party.
But in the 1800s, neighboring Cape May was a big summertime draw for Harrison and a number of other presidents.
Most of them stayed at Congress Hall, which Harrison made his "summer White House."
"By the middle of the 19th century, Cape May had become a booming holiday destination, rivaling Saratoga and Newport for popularity," the Congress Hall website noted.
While Trump is coming to Cape May County to campaign, previous presidents sought seaside relaxation.
Here's a look at their time at the shore:
Franklin Pierce, 1855 Many find the ocean air restorative, and that was apparently what lured President Franklin Pierce and his wife, Jane.
A July 5, 1855, article in the Pittsfield Sun reported "President Pierce and Mrs. Pierce are on a visit to Cape Island, N.J., for the health of the latter. They arrived there from Washington on Thursday."
Cape Island was renamed Cape May in 1869.
James Buchanan, 1867 Health concerns also brought former President James Buchanan to the shore. "His health, we regret to say, is quite feeble," reported an Aug. 25, 1867, New York Times article.
"He is suffering from extreme debility, the effect of a bilious attack which occurred on his return from Cape May, where he has been passing some weeks," the article added.
His trip apparently ended on a better note, with the article noting "he was decidedly better yesterday."
Buchanan would only live until the following summer but the shore trip apparently brought short-term relief.
Ulysses S. Grant, 1873-75 Grant made four visits to Cape May with his wife, Julia, in the summer of 1873, staying at Congress Hall.
In July 1875, Grant arrived in Cape May about a U.S. revenue cutter along with dignitaries who included a judge, governor and general.
The visit was quite a big deal, reported the New York Times.
"Their arrival was announced by the booming of cannon and demonstrations of enthusiasm. The distinguished visitors will witness the grand regatta, which promises to congregate more people than ever previously assembled on the island."
Chester Arthur, 1883 Forget fighting shore traffic. Arthur traveled to Cape May by presidential yacht, the USS Despatch. "After being ceremoniously escorted along the beach front, now Beach Avenue, the President was welcomed at the Stockton Hotel by the strains of 'Hail to the Chief,' played by Hassler's orchestra and the Weccacoe Band," according to the nearly century-old book "South Jersey: A History 1664-1924."
A local newspaper article added that on July 23, the night of his arrival, Arthur "managed to shake hands with upwards of 2,500 people."
Afterwards, the president met with "a few gentlemen who desired to see him socially."
"He said that he was greatly pleased with Cape May," the New York Times reported.
Benjamin Harrison, 1889-91 Even presidents like having a buddy with a shore house. For Harrison, it was famous Philadelphia retailer and Postmaster General John Wanamaker.
First lady Caroline Harrison and her family were guests at Wanamaker's Cape May cottage in June 1889; the president also paid a visit during that time, according to a 1974 Cape May newspaper article.
The next summer, the Harrisons stayed in a new shore cottage, a $10,000 gift from Wanamaker and William McLean, editor of the Philadelphia Public Ledger (An 1890 New York Times article noted that the president later paid for the home). In the summer of 1891, Harrison spent all but one week of the summer season at Congress Hall, the "summer White House."
While the president found the shore a conducive environment for work, his wife enjoyed the leisure activities.
Caroline Harrison "was probably the most powerful and biggest booster of Cape May County in history," the 1974 article said. "Mrs. Harrison was caught up in the social life of the shore and often took carriage rides through the area."
The shore was an escape from the scrutiny the couple faced at the White House, the article noted: "Cape residents did respect the privacy of President and Mrs. Harrison and did fend off the hordes of reporters that swarmed over the area."
Sheri Berkery is the trending reporter at the Courier-Post, covering the topics that people are talking about on social media and in real life. If you think you have a story idea that's a "talker," contact her at 856.486.2673 or sberkery@gannettnj.com
Help support local journalism with a Courier-Post subscription.
If the Black Friday craziness is bumming you out, kick back at Cape May's Congress Hall for a more laid-back evening.
PHOTO PROVIDED
Congress Hall was the "summer White House" for President Benjamin Harrison in 1891. Many other presidents stayed at the Cape May hotel. While Cape May County has hosted presidents since the 1800s, Donald Trump will be the first sitting president to visit Wildwood.
Congress Hall

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Envelope%2C+please%3A+2020%27s+children%27s+book+awards&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=Z.79&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Get ready to clap or groan or throw your hands up and say, "Huh?"
Why? Because very soon, the American Library Association will announce the Youth Media Awards. View the winners live on Monday, Jan. 27, starting at 6 a.m. Arizona time at ala.unikron.com
The ALA Youth Media Awards honors the year's best original and creative work in children's literature, including the prestigious Newbery, Caldecott, Printz and Coretta Scott King awards.
To make the 2020 decisions, committees composed of librarians and other literature and media experts spent hours reading, reviewing, and discussing books. They were not alone! A quick internet search displayed numerous hearty deliberations. Everyone from teachers to parents to booksellers had opinions. Oh, but what about children? Certainly, they have opinions. Perhaps surprisingly, they are NOT a part of the decision making process. So, before the announcements are made, let's review criteria for the two oldest awards: The John Newbery and the Randolph J. Caldecott.
According to the Association for Library Services for Children, the Newbery Medal is awarded annually for the most distinguished American children's book published in the United States in English during the previous year.
The idea was proposed on June 22, 1921, by Frederic G. Melcher, who suggested it be named for 18th-century English bookseller John Newbery. When approved, the Newbery Award became the first children's book award in the world.
The committee that reviews the books for any given year looks for both literary quality and superior presentation for children. The ALA further states that the author is a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. Along with the winner, honor books are announced.
The ALA indicates that the Caldecott Medal is awarded to the artist of the "most distinguished American picture book for children published in the United States during the preceding year." When you read any Caldecott winner, remember the award is for illustration, not story. Although, the words must be worthy of the illustrations.
As with the Newbery Award, the artist must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. Recently, Leonard S. Marcus, distinguished American author and children's literature expert, wrote an op-ed in the New York Times recommending that the Caldecott receive a makeover, an international one! He proposes abolishing the rule that candidates must be American.
According to Marcus, in 1938, when the ALA introduced the Caldecott, the United States was still a "cultural stepchild of Europe." At that time, British picture books like "The Adventures of Peter Rabbit" by Beatrix Potter had a stronghold on American children. By limiting Caldecott eligibility to American citizens and permanent residents, the ALA hoped to spark American creativity in illustration, just as they had done for the literary Newbery Award over a decade earlier.
Marcus insists that illustrations in picture books with their "beguiling cultural inflection" provide children with a universal language and the "American only" metric is pointless in today's world. Marcus is well respected, but redesigning the Caldecott Medal for worldwide eligibility is the sole decision of the ALA. Presently, the Caldecott Medal remains uniquely American. This year, like previous years, the suspense and excitement of the announcement will bubble over in homes, libraries and schools. I hope you watch the unveiling ceremony!
Anita N. Voelker, Ph.D., is a children's book enthusiast, reading specialist. Contact her at avoelker51@cox.net

____________________________________________________________

Tech execs becoming victims of swatting attacks, police say

Autor: Frenkel, Sheera. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 25 Jan 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/tech-execs-becoming-victims-swatting-attacks/docview/2344507613/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Tech+execs+becoming+victims+of+swatting+attacks%2C+police+say&amp;author=Frenkel%2C+Sheera&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: SAN FRANCISCO - Over the first week of November, the police in San Francisco and New York responded to a series of telephone calls claiming that hostages were being held in the homes of Adam Mosseri, a senior Facebook executive.
The calls appeared to be coming from inside the homes.
Officers arrived in force and barricaded the streets outside. Twice.
But after tense, hourslong standoffs, they realized the calls were hoaxes. There were no hostages, and no one in the homes had called the police.
Mosseri is one of a number of tech executives who have been targeted recently in so-called swatting incidents. Swatting is online lingo used to describe when people call the police with false reports of a violent crime of some sort inside a home, hoping to persuade them to send a SWAT team.
These episodes have become more common in communities rich with tech companies and their billionaire executives, like the Bay Area and Seattle, according to six police departments contacted by The New York Times.
Exact numbers are unclear, police say, because there is no central repository of information for these sorts of attacks.
But as online discourse has become more combative and more personal, some in the industry aren't surprised that tech executives - the people who decide what is posted on social media and who is barred from it - have become regular targets.
Swattings have spiked at Facebook in particular, according to local police departments and security officials at the company, which in recent years has cracked down on false accounts, threatening language and other types of content that violates its rules. They spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity surrounding the attacks.
Mosseri declined to comment, and a Facebook spokesman, Anthony Harrison, said in a statement that "because these things deal with security matters and our employees, we are unable to comment."
The attacks have been aided by forums that have sprung up both on the public internet and on the camouflaged sites of the so-called dark web. These forums name thousands of people, from high-ranking executives to their extended families, who could be targets, providing cellphone numbers, home addresses and other information. Some even discuss techniques that can be used - like cheap, online technology that can spoof a phone number and make the police believe a 911 call is coming from a target's home.
In the eight months since one online forum was started, nearly 3,000 people have joined.
"Who should we do next?" read one message on the forum last month. The responses included gun emojis - the symbol, in swatting forums, for an attack in which the police were successfully called to the target's home. Many of the responses were laced with profanity, as well as suggestions for ex-girlfriends who should be swatted.
One forum names at least two dozen Facebook employees as potential targets. They range from executives to product engineers. Some forum participants said that they had been barred from Facebook or Instagram, and that Facebook employees were fair game because they "think they are god."
Swatting started in the combative world of online gaming. It was a way to terrorize someone more famous, get even with a rival or retaliate against someone with different political views.
Provoking a heavily armed police response presents obvious risks. Last year, a 26-year-old California man was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison for calling in dozens of fake emergency calls, including one that led to the fatal police shooting of Andrew Finch, a Kansas resident.
Caption: Adam Mosseri, a senior Facebook executive, is one of a number of tech executive targeted in swatting incidents.
RICKY RHODES/The New York Times 2019

____________________________________________________________

What's ahead for the Orioles?

Autor: Pollitt, Richard. 

Información de publicación: Daily Times ; Salisbury, Md. [Salisbury, Md]. 25 Jan 2020: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/whats-ahead-orioles/docview/2344506206/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=What%27s+ahead+for+the+Orioles%3F%3A+GM+Elias+provides+some+answers+at+Shorebirds%27+hot+stove+banquet&amp;author=Pollitt%2C+Richard&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Times&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Mike Elias isn't saying much about the Houston Astros' sign-stealing scandal that rocked Major League Baseball, despite being a part of the organization when the incident occurred.
"I'm not going to give an in-depth comment on the topic, but we're going to do things the right way with the Orioles," he said.
Instead, Elias is focused on his second season as general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, acting as a guest speaker at the Delmarva Shorebirds' annual hot stove banquet on Thursday night.
The event serves as an opportunity for fans and officials to come together to talk baseball.
The Shorebirds are just four months removed from their historic 2019 season that saw the club win 90 games and advance to the postseason for the first time since 2005. The squad was led by a strong group of pitchers, highlighted by Grayson Rodriguez and Drew Rom, and solid position players, such as infielder Adam Hall and outfielder Robert Neustrom.
Delmarva also hosted 2019 No. 1 overall selection Adley Rutschman toward the end of the season. Elias said he would like to see the catcher start the upcoming season with the Frederick Keys, however it will depend on his performance in spring training.
But Thursday night was about 2020 and how the Shorebirds, and Orioles, would find ways to succeed.
Baltimore was the second worst team in the MLB last season, finishing the year with a 54-108 overall record. However, with a young core expected to make the big-league club, the Orioles' general manger is confident the organization's rebuild is going as planned.
"Some of the names we've been reading about are going to start to arrive in Camden Yards," Elias said. "It's still about player development and those individual performances and not necessarily the team's win and loss record. Those guys are taking steps forward, graduating to the big leagues and adjusting to big-league life."
Elias also expressed his satisfaction with Baltimore's minor-league system.
The Bowie Baysox — the Orioles' Double-A affiliate — also advanced to the postseason, while the Aberdeen Ironbirds — the short-season club — finished with some of their best numbers in history.
After leading the club in 2019, Shorebirds' manager Kyle Moore was promoted to Frederick, replacing longtime skipper Ryan Minor who was let go from the organization. Dave Anderson, who has been with the Orioles the last six years, most recently as a minor-league infield coordinator, will take over on Delmarva.
"It's exactly what you want to see, especially when you're in a rebuild," he said. "We're focused on that type of success. The success of teams like the Shorebirds is really going to dictate what we do the next couple of years in Baltimore."
In November, news broke that several minor-league teams throughout the country were on the chopping block as part of a new MLB plan to streamline its minor league system for efficiency and to improve conditions for players, according to a New York Times report. The Frederick Keys was one of 42 clubs on the list.
While nothing is official, minor-league officials have said they'll do everything in their power to prevent the loss of any team. Elias provided little information on the status of Frederick or how the Orioles will respond should they lose any club.
"All I know is that this is being handled at the league level," he said. "I think Major League Baseball wants to see a healthier player development environment, and minor-league baseball has a lot of interest as well, and I'm sure both sides will come up with a solution."
Though he couldn't say much, Elias did respond to questions about the recent situation regarding the Astros.
Recently, The Athletic reported the Astros had used technology to steal opposing teams' signs that allowed Houston batters to know what type of pitch was coming. The Astros would go on to win the 2017 World Series.
Once news of the scandal broke, Houston was fined $5 million by the MLB and forced to forfeit draft picks in the 2020 and 2021 MLB Draft. General manager Jeff Luhnow and field manager A.J. Hinch were fired following a suspension sent down by the league.
Elias served as Houston's assistant general manager and oversaw player development and minor-league operations before coming to Baltimore in 2018.
Elias said his primary duties in Houston were dealing with the minor leagues and scouting, noting the scandal doesn't detract from the work he and his staff did in those areas.
"I think there's a history of things happening in our sport and other sports, and that's why we have good people in the sport to get it fixed and be better," Elias said.
While one general manager spoke of the future, the other highlighted the success of 2019 and discussed some notable events taking place at Arthur W. Perdue Stadium next season.
Coming off a 90-win season, Shorebirds' general manager Chris Bitters is excited to have fans back at the ballfield watching some of the Orioles' top prospects.
"We're kicking off baseball for bird land right here in Salisbury," he said. "Last year was the cherry on top. We had all these great things going on and then boom, we catapult to best team record in team history.
"We had exciting baseball every night."
The Shorebirds also unveiled their promotional schedule for 2020, which includes several giveaways and theme nights.
A Trey Mancini Jedi bobblehead will be given away on May 8, while a Hawaiian shirt giveaway will take place on June 26. Theme nights include Harry Potter (May 22) and Nickelodeon Night (July 17).
"There's going to be great opportunities throughout the year for the fans to come out and enjoy a giveaway, fireworks night or a value night," Bitters said.
Delmarva kicks off its season April 8 at home against the Asheville Tourists. Team rosters will be announced following spring training.
CREDIT: Richard Pollitt

____________________________________________________________

Hail to the beach: A brief history of presidents visiting Cape May County

Autor: Berkery, Sheri. 

Información de publicación: Courier Post ; Cherry Hill, N.J. [Cherry Hill, N.J]. 25 Jan 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hail-beach-brief-history-presidents-visiting-cape/docview/2344505991/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Hail+to+the+beach%3A+A+brief+history+of+presidents+visiting+Cape+May+County&amp;author=Berkery%2C+Sheri&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+Post&amp;issn=1050-432X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: When President Donald Trump holds a rally in Wildwood on Jan. 28, he will be surrounded by cellphones, webcams and giant screens.
That wasn't the case the last time a president visited Cape May County.
But then again, it was the 1890s.
Benjamin Harrison was reportedly the most recent presidential visitor in the county that will host Trump next week.
Trump will be the first sitting president in Wildwood — a location chosen because it's in the district of U.S. Rep Jeff Van Drew, who recently switched to the Republican party.
But in the 1800s, neighboring Cape May was a big summertime draw for Harrison and a number of other presidents.
Most of them stayed at Congress Hall, which Harrison made his "summer White House."
"By the middle of the 19th century, Cape May had become a booming holiday destination, rivaling Saratoga and Newport for popularity," the Congress Hall website noted.
While Trump is coming to Cape May County to campaign, previous presidents sought seaside relaxation.
Here's a look at their time at the shore:
Franklin Pierce, 1855 Many find the ocean air restorative, and that was apparently what lured President Franklin Pierce and his wife, Jane.
A July 5, 1855, article in the Pittsfield Sun reported "President Pierce and Mrs. Pierce are on a visit to Cape Island, N.J., for the health of the latter. They arrived there from Washington on Thursday."
Cape Island was renamed Cape May in 1869.
James Buchanan, 1867 Health concerns also brought former President James Buchanan to the shore. "His health, we regret to say, is quite feeble," reported an Aug. 25, 1867, New York Times article.
"He is suffering from extreme debility, the effect of a bilious attack which occurred on his return from Cape May, where he has been passing some weeks," the article added.
His trip apparently ended on a better note, with the article noting "he was decidedly better yesterday."
Buchanan would only live until the following summer but the shore trip apparently brought short-term relief.
Ulysses S. Grant, 1873-75 Grant made four visits to Cape May with his wife, Julia, in the summer of 1873, staying at Congress Hall.
In July 1875, Grant arrived in Cape May about a U.S. revenue cutter along with dignitaries who included a judge, governor and general.
The visit was quite a big deal, reported the New York Times.
"Their arrival was announced by the booming of cannon and demonstrations of enthusiasm. The distinguished visitors will witness the grand regatta, which promises to congregate more people than ever previously assembled on the island."
Chester Arthur, 1883 Forget fighting shore traffic. Arthur traveled to Cape May by presidential yacht, the USS Despatch. "After being ceremoniously escorted along the beach front, now Beach Avenue, the President was welcomed at the Stockton Hotel by the strains of 'Hail to the Chief,' played by Hassler's orchestra and the Weccacoe Band," according to the nearly century-old book "South Jersey: A History 1664-1924."
A local newspaper article added that on July 23, the night of his arrival, Arthur "managed to shake hands with upwards of 2,500 people."
Afterwards, the president met with "a few gentlemen who desired to see him socially."
"He said that he was greatly pleased with Cape May," the New York Times reported.
Benjamin Harrison, 1889-91 Even presidents like having a buddy with a shore house. For Harrison, it was famous Philadelphia retailer and Postmaster General John Wanamaker.
First lady Caroline Harrison and her family were guests at Wanamaker's Cape May cottage in June 1889; the president also paid a visit during that time, according to a 1974 Cape May newspaper article.
The next summer, the Harrisons stayed in a new shore cottage, a $10,000 gift from Wanamaker and William McLean, editor of the Philadelphia Public Ledger (An 1890 New York Times article noted that the president later paid for the home).
In the summer of 1891, Harrison spent all but one week of the summer season at Congress Hall, the "summer White House."
While the president found the shore a conducive environment for work, his wife enjoyed the leisure activities.
Caroline Harrison "was probably the most powerful and biggest booster of Cape May County in history," the 1974 article said. "Mrs. Harrison was caught up in the social life of the shore and often took carriage rides through the area."
The shore was an escape from the scrutiny the couple faced at the White House, the article noted: "Cape residents did respect the privacy of President and Mrs. Harrison and did fend off the hordes of reporters that swarmed over the area."
Sheri Berkery is the trending reporter at the Courier-Post, covering the topics that people are talking about on social media and in real life. If you think you have a story idea that's a "talker," contact her at 856.486.2673 or sberkery@gannettnj.com
Congress Hall was the "summer White House" for President Benjamin Harrison in 1891. Many other presidents stayed at the Cape May hotel. While Cape May County has hosted presidents since the 1800s, Donald Trump will be the first sitting president to visit Wildwood.
courtesy of Congress Hall
Pierce
Buchanan
Grant
Arthur
Harrison

A quick internet search displayed numerous hearty deliberations. Everyone from teachers to parents to booksellers had opinions.
Oh, but what about children? Certainly, they have opinions. Perhaps surprisingly, they are NOT a part of the decision making process. So, before the announcements are made, let's review criteria for the two oldest awards: The John Newbery and the Randolph J. Caldecott.
According to the Association for Library Services for Children, the Newbery Medal is awarded annually for the most distinguished American children's book published in the United States in English during the previous year.

The ALA indicates that the Caldecott Medal is awarded to the artist of the "most distinguished American picture book for children published in the United States during the preceding year." He proposes abolishing the rule that candidates must be American.

Marcus is well respected, but redesigning the Caldecott Medal for worldwide eligibility is the sole decision of the ALA.
Presently, the Caldecott Medal remains uniquely American. This year, like previous years, the suspense and excitement of the announcement will bubble over in homes, libraries and schools. I hope you watch the unveiling ceremony!

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Información de publicación: Arizona Republic ; Phoenix, Ariz. [Phoenix, Ariz]. 25 Jan 2020: Z.78.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/letters-editor/docview/2344505771/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=LETTERS+TO+THE+EDITOR%3A+HOA+HAS+A+DARK+HEART&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=Z.78&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: HOA's are entitled to have and enforce certain rules. But shouldn't they also be expected to show some compassion for a tragically orphaned teen? ("HOA wants to kick orphaned teen out of grandparents' house," Jan. 15).
Would they force him to live on the streets? Or perhaps worse, be sentenced to years in the foster care system?
I wonder if any HOA board member would force his own grandchild out of the only family home left to him!
K. D. Myrick, Phoenix
Not another stadium? Thank you for reporting on the Akimel 7 development project earlier this week. I was surprised to learn that tax credits are going to a project that includes plans for a new professional sports arena.
The article hints that the new arena may lure the Coyotes or Diamondbacks to the East Valley. That move would leave a vacant stadium downtown or in Glendale.
Arizona Veterans Memorial Coliseum is a near-vacant arena that is both close to downtown and on the west side. Since we already have a near-vacant stadium serving those areas, tax incentives should not be used to create another.
Paul Franckowiak, Laveen
Classless leader in high-class city I'm a proud resident of Scottsdale, and we are touted as a high-class city. On the other hand, it's confounding why we continue to elect a low-class politician like Jay Lawrence — an admitted bigot, and purveyor of conspiracies?
Seems to me to be very low standards for an electorate I know is well educated and looking for the best for our city and state.
Jeff Jameson, Scottsdale
Trust schools with sex ed? I am skeptical of public schools teaching sex education. After all, these are the people that can't seem to properly teach their mandated curriculum of English, science and math. And you want to entrust them with sex education?
Kathy Diekelman, Chandler
Virtue signaling at APS It's wonderful that APS plans on becoming carbon free by 2050 (even though they admit the technology to do that doesn't exist). However, APS's goal will be meaningless virtue signaling unless APS and the rest of us become China Free.
China is the worst climate criminal and, as the New York Times recently reported, is growing its coal-burning, climate changing CO2 footprint at home and abroad.
As long as APS and the rest of us keep buying products produced by China or unless China stops its evil ways (don't count on that), Arizona and America won't be carbon free.
Jim McManus, Phoenix
What would Flake and McCain do? What if Senators Jeff Flake and John McCain were still our representatives during Trump's Senate impeachment trial? What would we Arizonans be facing?
They both butted heads with the president and perhaps would have sided with the facts instead of ignoring the truth. Nixon resigned not long after he'd lost the support of Arizona Sen. Barry Goldwater and Rep. John Rhodes.
Country over party is sadly no more.
Armando Arvizu, Phoenix
Join the conversation: E-mail your My Turn of no more than 650 words leah.trinidad@arizonarepublic.com. Send your Letters to the Editor to opinions@arizonarepublic.com. Include your address and phone number for verification.

Lugar: China New York Arizona

Personas: Flake, Jeff McCain, John

Marcus is well respected, but redesigning the Caldecott Medal for worldwide eligibility is the sole decision of the ALA.
Presently, the Caldecott Medal remains uniquely American. This year, like previous years, the suspense and excitement of the announcement will bubble over in homes, libraries and schools. I hope you watch the unveiling ceremony!

History books tell the tale of two Americas

Información de publicación: Morning Sentinel ; Waterville, Me. [Waterville, Me]. 25 Jan 2020: 1.A.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/history-books-tell-tale-two-americas/docview/2344500968/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=History+books+tell+the+tale+of+two+Americas&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.A&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Morning+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: When former New York senator and scholar Daniel Patrick Moynihan died in 2003, he was celebrated for his hugely productive careers in both politics and academia, and admired for his wit. His aphorism — “You are entitled to your opinion. But you are not entitled to your own facts.” — was often cited.
But as the 21st century careens along, Moynihan’s premise has taken a beating. Technology has made it easier for ideologues to only get information that reinforces their existing views. Moynihan’s assumption that people could carry on arguments over policy issues while agreeing on basic facts has been obliterated. The most prominent examples: Those on the left like to cite the skepticism many conservatives have about climate change, which runs counter to the views of the vast majority of scientists. And those on the right often bring up the warnings many progressives make about the risks of genetically modified food, which also are contrary to the views of the vast majority of scientists.
This partisan framing goes far beyond such high-profile issues. Every day, Americans can watch TV shows, check out websites or listen to podcasts that present not just different opinions but different factual frameworks. And as a deeply troubling recent story in The New York Times pointed out, this fact shading is now common in school textbooks.
The New York Times analyzed eight of the most popular history textbooks used in both California and Texas public schools — textbooks with the same authors and same publishers. In both states, laws have been passed and teaching standards set that reflect the values of state lawmakers and members of the state board of education. As a result, there are now basic differences in how the history books in America’s two most populous states deal with such profound issues as race and the economy.
In discussions of the “white flight” phenomenon from the 1950s and 1960s in which millions of white Americans moved from big cities to more homogenous suburbs, the California history textbook published by McGraw-Hill says some of these Americans were “driven by a desire to get away from more culturally diverse neighborhoods” — i.e., racism. The Texas textbook states that some of these Americans “wished to escape the crime and congestion of the city” — also loaded language.
In discussions of capitalism, The New York Times noted California textbooks “sometimes read like a brief from a Bernie Sanders rally.” Those in Texas celebrate the wealth-creating free-market economy.
The same differences are apparent in how the textbooks deal with everything from gun rights and the Harlem Renaissance to immigration and gender. In California, The New York Times noted, education bureaucrats persuaded one textbook publisher to not use the word “massacre” to describe how 19th-century Native Americans responded to white settlers. In Texas, they got another publisher to emphasize religious values of America’s founders.
The sad news is there is little reason to hope that this front in America’s ongoing culture wars is going to change. A survey of 8,000 Americans released in 2018 by researchers at YouGov and the More in Common civics group found that while most Americans are generally centrist, 14% of residents are “starkly polarized” people on the left and right who tend to “dominate public debate in the digital age.”
Such Californians and Texans likely love their state officials putting their thumbs on the scales in the teaching of history. But the rest of us should fear this as one more sign of the clout of a relative handful of Americans who reject ideas that don’t fit in with their worldview, facts be damned or shaded.
American history has long been framed by those who write it. That’s clearer the more divided we get.
Editorial by The San Diego Union-Tribune

Materia: Textbooks; Black history

Lugar: Texas California New York

Personas: Sanders, Bernard Moynihan, Daniel P

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120; Nombre: San Diego Union-Tribune; NAICS: 511110

Título: History books tell the tale of two Americas

Título de publicación: Morning Sentinel; Waterville, Me.

Primera página: 1.A

Año de publicación: 2020

Fecha de publicación: Jan 25, 2020

Editorial: Morning Sentinel

Lugar de publicación: Waterville, Me.

País de publicación: United States, Waterville, Me.

In discussions of the “white flight” phenomenon from the 1950s and 1960s in which millions of white Americans moved from big cities to more homogenous suburbs, the California history textbook published by McGraw-Hill says some of these Americans were “driven by a desire to get away from more culturally diverse neighborhoods” — i.e., racism. The Texas textbook states that some of these Americans “wished to escape the crime and congestion of the city” — also loaded language.
In discussions of capitalism, The New York Times noted California textbooks “sometimes read like a brief from a Bernie Sanders rally.” Those in Texas celebrate the wealth-creating free-market economy.
The same differences are apparent in how the textbooks deal with everything from gun rights and the Harlem Renaissance to immigration and gender. In California, The New York Times noted, education bureaucrats persuaded one textbook publisher to not use the word “massacre” to describe how 19th-century Native Americans responded to white settlers. In Texas, they got another publisher to emphasize religious values of America’s founders.
The sad news is there is little reason to hope that this front in America’s ongoing culture wars is going to change. A survey of 8,000 Americans released in 2018 by researchers at YouGov and the More in Common civics group found that while most Americans are generally centrist, 14% of residents are “starkly polarized” people on the left and right who tend to “dominate public debate in the digital age.”
Such Californians and Texans likely love their state officials putting their thumbs on the scales in the teaching of history. But the rest of us should fear this as one more sign of the clout of a relative handful of Americans who reject ideas that don’t fit in with their worldview, facts be damned or shaded.
American history has long been framed by those who write it. That’s clearer the more divided we get.
Editorial by The San Diego Union-Tribune

BOOKS 'CLEAN GETAWAY': Novel follows child on journey of secrets: Author Nic Stone's novel 'Clean Getaway' addresses racism in inspired way.

Autor: Bentley, Rosalind. 

Información de publicación: The Atlanta Journal - Constitution ; Atlanta, Ga. [Atlanta, Ga]. 25 Jan 2020: D.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/books-clean-getaway-novel-follows-child-on/docview/2344493828/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=BOOKS+%27CLEAN+GETAWAY%27%3A+Novel+follows+child+on+journey+of+secrets%3A+Author+Nic+Stone%27s+novel+%27Clean+Getaway%27+addresses+racism+in+inspired+way.&amp;author=Bentley%2C+Rosalind&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;date=2020-01-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Atlanta+Journal+-+Constitution&amp;issn=1539-7459&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Author Nic Stone faced a challenge.
Her debut, young adult novel, "Dear Martin," became a 2017 New York Times bestseller and earned her praise for its of-the-moment take on the effects of racial profiling on young black men and teens, regardless of their economic status and level of academic achievement. Her portrayal was direct and searing.
But even as her next two YA novels, "Odd One Out," and "Jackpot: All Bet$ Are Off," were well
received, Stone still got comments from elementary school teachers and parents who'd read "Dear Martin," but wondered if she planned to deal with hard questions of race and identity in a novel appropriate for third through sixth graders.The Atlanta author and Spelman graduate understood. She and her husband have sons: 7 years old and 3 years old.
"I wanted to be able to address racism without calling it that," Stone said recently.
Her new and fourth novel, "Clean Getaway," does that in an inspired way. The protagonist is an 11-year-old middle school student, William "Scoob" Lamar, an African American boy who is gifted at writing computer code. But in the book, some are doubtful that a black kid can be good at something other than music and sports. More tumult ensues, and Scoob finds himself suspended from school. That's where the adventure begins.
Initiated by his grandmother, who is white, the two embark on a trip through the South in her Winnebago following stops listed in the real-life, and perhaps life-saving, "The Negro Motorist Green Book." The volumes were published from 1936 to 1966 to help African American travelers find safe lodging during the dangerous era of segregation.
But as the trip progresses, Scoob realizes there's something off about his grandmother. Why is she behaving so oddly? And why is she fixated on fine jewelry? The questions build from city to city, RV park to RV park. This is a kid's novel as much about secrets and presumptions as it is about race.
"We all have things our children don't know about us," Stone said. "There are some things my grandmother shared with me about my granddaddy once, that I was like, 'Whoa! I'm not sure I really wanted to know that, but now I do.' Once you run up against it, you have to address it."
Stone -- who made it a point to say the Green Book experience she constructed has nothing to do with the contentious 2018 film, "The Green Book" -- pulled other elements from her own life as inspiration. Just as Scoob's grandmother is white, so is Stone's mother-in-law, the grandmother to her two sons. Stone's husband has a Nigerian father and a Russian mother.
"She married a Nigerian man in Russia in the 1970s," Stone said. "Being in an interracial marriage during the civil rights movement was something I wanted to explore."
The author also wanted to introduce young readers to the idea that their grandparents were young once too. They lived full lives and did things they were proud of as well as things they wished they'd done differently.
"We completely erase a person's history," Stone said. "You just don't wake up 70 years old. It's our own shame as adults that keeps us from being honest est with the children in our lives. Just tell your grandkids grand- the truth of your life." As Scoob learns about the
evils of segregation and the courage it took to battle it, he also learns lessons that may help him confront more subtle forms of racism still alive and well. Just as important, he learns that presumptions, whether about race or age, can be restricting. Acknowledging them and dealing with them takes maturity and courage.
(Box)
